mainheading: Cochin Refineries School celebrated its 51st foundation day
subheading: Cochin Refineries School established in 1966, is situated on the picturesque hill top of Jwalagiri.The school is run by Cochin Refineries Educational Aid Society and managed by Board of Governors nominated by the management of BPCL Kochi Refinery.
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
On Friday, Cochin Refineries School celebrated its 51st foundation day in >founded for the children of employees of erstwhile Kochi Refineries Ltd.

A P M Mohammed Hanish IAS, Chairman & MD Kerala State Civil Supplies Corporation was the chief guest of this event and congratulated both students and staffs for completing another year of success.

 He said “I had to work in tandem with the Bharat petroleum when I was the district collector of Ernakulam. I use to speak about the dedication, professionalism and the tremendous deal of commitment showed not only for the In-house activities but also the outreach activities they had for the well being of people in the society. As children of these officers sitting here, I think Cochin refineries School should be in its heights of excellence and ultimately reach the pinnacle of glory and say to the whole nation that here is an institution that did not just produce studious students but indeed produce various citizens.”

“When it comes to the Cochin Refineries School this has become the collection of brilliance that is expounded by the officers and staff alike and it ultimately becomes the way for proper education. This education is complete only when the things learned in classrooms get harmoniously blended with whatever is to be provided from outside.  Education is not about just providing what is taught in classrooms. Beyond the textbooks or any authoritative books, it is always a question of the interaction with nature and also the various give and take that an individual has with the society in which he is placed” said Mohammed Hanish.

The celebrations started with a public function where the annual report of 2016-17 was presented, school magazine was released and honoured the winners who achieved excellence in academic and non-academic fields with prizes and were followed by various entertainments. The annual report was presented by Mala B Menon, Principal of the school and the School magazine was unveiled by  M V Prabhakaran, chairman of the school board.

mainheading: Short film awards to be announced on August 26
subheading: Screenscapes 2017 is a seven-day interschool short film challenge organised by Westford Institute of Film Technology along with Greets Public School.
author: Db Correspondent
article: The challenge themed under ‘Fear’ was finished on August 14 with students of 9 to 12 classes from more than 60 schools participating. The jury which includes eminent film directors of Malayalam film industry like Shayamdhar, Jude Antony Joseph and Dileesh Nair will announce the winners August 26 Saturday at a public event in Greets Public School. 35 selected short films will be screened during the show.

mainheading: Students in Kochi hit the floor in public to remind Hiroshima-Nagasaki Day
subheading: It was on 06 and 09 August in 1945 that Hiroshima and Nagasaki were hit by nuclear bombs
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
Students of Mary Matha Public School, Thrikkakara organised a flash mob on Wednesday at Kakkand open-air stage to remember the nuclear bombings of two Japanese cities and to spread the message of denuclearization of the world. Abdul Mutalib, district panchayat vice president, gave the peace message and school principal Sister Soja Maria read out a pledge for a world without war. 

It was on 06 and 09 August in 1945 that Hiroshima and Nagasaki were hit by nuclear bombs during the second world war. It was the first ever warfare execution of this deadly weapon causing 129,000 deaths and significant casualties. The people of these two cities still bear the after-effects of these bombings even after the 72nd anniversary of the event. 

"This day is a reminder of the fact that we all are brothers and sisters and must work towards a peaceful world with no nuclear weapons. Let us appreciate the student's teachers and the school which initiated such a reminder to the society", said Abdul Mutalib. He also released a white pigeon as a symbol of peace while inaugurating the function. A N Shaju, sub-inspector, Kakkanad Janamithri police station were also present.

mainheading: Students of Bhavan's Girinagar won ‘Best Short Film Award’ in Screenscapes 2017.
subheading: Screenscapes 2017 is a seven-day interschool short film challenge organised by Westford Institute of Film Technology along with Greets Public School.
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
Phayam (ഫയം), the film made by the students of Bhavan's Vidya Mandir, Girinagar had won the award for ‘Best Short Film’ in a function held on August 26, 2017, at Greets Public School, Kaloor. The team was presented with a trophy, certificate and Rs.25000.

Screenscapes 2017, the Inter-School Short Film Festival organized by Westford Institute of Film Technology in association with Greets Public School, was assessed by a panel of judges including Director Shyamdhar, Director and Actor Dileesh Pothen, Scriptwriter Dileesh Nair and Director Jude Anthany Joseph. The filmmakers also shared their experience of the hardships and fun they had during the making of the movies.

Jess Thaddeus of Rajagiri Christu Jayanthi Public School, Kakkanad won the award for ‘Best Director’ for the film ‘Bridge’, while ‘Best Scriptwriter’ was Susan Ben from Assisi Vidyaniketan Public School, Perumpilly writing for the film ‘Nirbhaya’ (നിർഭയ).

Arjun Kumar of Bhavan’s Vidhya Mandir, Elamakkara became the ‘Best Actor’ for acting in the film ‘Kochu Pustakam’ (കൊച്ചു പുസ്തകം) and Alina Meria Felix was selected as the ‘Best Actress’ for her performance in the film ‘Phobia’ of MGM, Kakkanad. Shooting for the seven-day challenge themed under ‘Fear’ was finished on August 14 with students of 9 to 12 classes from more than 60 schools participating.

Along with Actors Vinay Fort, Deepti Sati and singer Kumari Shreya Jayadeep, Thomas  Vadakekut, Chairman of Bethel Foundation, P Silaskutty, Superintendent and Treasurer, Sabu Thomas Vadakekut, Director and Managing Trustee, Thomas Sabu Vadakekut, Member of School Managing Committee were present during the occasion.

mainheading: Students of St. Albert’s HSS extend their hands for the hungry
subheading: ‘The good Samaritan’ is a project launched by the students to feed the hungry
author: Db Correspondent
article:
If you know the city well or even if you have visited it for once, you may have come across plenty of the homeless, hungry and needy people in the streets. Soon you will also start to see the uniformed school students bringing lunch packets and feeding them with delicious food at High Court Junction or Bus stands or even in railway stations. They are the students of St. Albert’s Higher Secondary School who took an initiative to open their hands and reach out to the hungry every week.

‘The good Samaritan’, as it is called, is a unique project launched by the students in a joint venture with JRC in August 2017 and are planned to continue throughout the year. Weekly turns are given to the classes so that all students can contribute and know that these simple deeds of goodness can make changes in society.

Rev. Fr. Felix Chullikal, general manager, St. Albert’s HSS inaugurated the project and appreciated the goodwill of students to helps the needy and homeless. Love and Care is a city-based organization which helps the students to distribute it in different parts of the metropolis.

mainheading: The first ‘Magic Tree’ got planted at St. Albert’s HSS
subheading: The project aims to build environmental awareness and interaction among students by planting and nurturing a tree in every school.
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
With the concept of ‘One School One Tree’, ‘The Daybreak’ has launched its first ever campaign here on Thursday. ‘Magic Tree’ has got inaugurated by Fr. Felix Chullikal, general manager of St. Alberts Higher Secondary School by planting a Banyan tree on its campus with a crowd of young minds.

The project is an attempt to develop the culture close to nature and inculcate them into the young minds of the city by planting a tree in every school and let students travel through the entire process of its growth.

While planting the tree Fr. Felix said “St. Albert’s HSS is already a great example for protecting the nature, as we could see that every tree inside the campus is flourishing ever since they are planted due to the care we give. We are also on a mission to grow more fruit trees and medicinal plants so that students can benefit from them”.

“The school had encouraged all sorts of attempts to mingle with nature and we stand firmly with ‘The Daybreak’ and the team for their enthusiasm to plant trees and nurture them for good”, he continued.

 From planting to protecting, from watering to fertilising, The Daybreak ensures the student’s participation in every single step with regular inspections. The team also targets the characterization of each tree by installing a box which allows students to interact and ask questions.

The manure used as the medium for the plant is purely made out of waste through natural composting methods.

Amalnath, director of ‘The Daybreak’, said “Greenery is the most crucial factor that we all and the coming generations desperately need. The Daybreak is taking an initiative not to just plant a tree but to create a culture based on the tree. We want you the students, the promise of future to take care of the plant and interact with us at every stage of its development.”

The team is looking forward to more ‘Magic Trees’ to be planted very soon.

mainheading: The Govt School that walks way ahead in digital education
subheading: Students of Chorode Government Higher Secondary School communicate with educators and students from more than 20 different countries including United States, Japan, Greece and Pakistan.
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
Much before the Government of Kerala’s introduction of Smart Classes and its investment into the digitalization of public schools, a school in Kozhikode district of Kerala has travelled much deep into the world digital education.

 With more than 40 sessions every year, the classes through internet help them particularly in improving the English education and building a global identity. The school authorities encourage students to have cultural exchange and study from different perspectives to stimulate the process of education.

The school has permanent video conferencing system in its classrooms and for last seven years, the students use them communicate with educators and pupils around the world. These activities enabled students both in improving the language skills with courage and also in building cultural bridges with foreign countries to have their perspective on education.

Annamma Kumaran Syke who pioneered the idea of English education and cultural exchange through the digital medium is teaching English in the school and was supported by management and PTA.  He also conducted webinar series, for the first time in Kerala, meeting people in different countries at the same time. 

Andru Thayyullathil, Head Master, Chorode GHSS, said “With the cooperation of people and PTA we have developed a space for digital education in our school which allows our teachers to make students exposed to the new developments around. Every division of our 10th standard have a permanent online projector system and have build facilities to interact with people anywhere in the world.”

mainheading: The Gods of Mount Olympus
author: Pravar Mukkala, 6th Grade
article:
You might know about all of the Indian Gods, but there are other gods, too. One really interesting set of gods are the Greek ones.

      Zeus is the son of Cronus and Rhea, two of the Titans. He is the god of the heavens, sky, clouds, lightning, and wields the power of thunder. He is the father of many of the Olympian Gods.His spouse is Hera, and she is also his sister. Now that is weird. But Hera is not the mother of many of the Olympian Gods. Zeus married many other women and had thousands of other children.

      Hera is the goddess of women, marriage, and childbirth.

      Athena is the goddess of wisdom and strategic warfare.  She battled Poseidon, the god of the seas and horses for the city of Attica, and won with the creation of the olive tree. The city was proudly renamed Athens. Athena was born in a rather strange way. Zeus’s wife at the time was Metis, and a prophecy told him that if it was a son, he would take over as a king. Zeus swallowed Metis and Athena burst out of Zeus’s head.

       Apollo and Artemis were born in a strange way, too. Hera made all the lands that had roots in the earth to not accept Leto, Apollo and Artemis’s mother, and when she was pregnant. At the time there was an island called Delos that floated around, occasionally bumping off other islands. Hera banished Eileithyia, the goddess of childbirth to go to help Leto. Finally, the other goddesses distracted Hera with a necklace and Eileithyia went and helped Leto. Out came Apollo and Artemis. Apollo, god of the sun, light, oracles, music, song, dance, healing, and medicine defeated the mighty Python, a huge snake when he was four days old, and Artemis, goddess of the wilderness and forests asked her father Zeus if she could be a maiden forever and not marry. These two gods are also the gods of archery.

      Ares was the son of Zeus and Hera, and Aphrodite was born from the remains of Ouranos, father of Cronus.  So technically she would be the great-aunt of Ares. Aphrodite had children with Ares, even though she was married to Hephaestus.

      Hades is the god of death and married his niece, Persephone, goddess of springtime, daughter of Zeus and Demeter, goddess of plants and the harvest.

I hope you learned a lot of stuff about the Gods of Mount Olympus!

mainheading: My Cousin Pachu
author: Gauri Santhosh
article:
Anyone who has a naughty sibling or cousin can definitely relate to this article. 6-year-olds in particular- They simply cannot keep still! They have to run haywire, darting here and there, causing all hell to break loose.

I’m going to tell you a couple of hilarious anecdotes about how I babysat my cousin Pachu during his visit to our home.

The havoc started two years ago when my uncle Manu, my aunty Priya and my cousin Pachu came to stay with us a day or two. When they were being shown around the house, the grown-ups suggested I take Pachu downstairs. I had no idea what I was getting myself into when I agreed.

Pachu was very excited to meet my best friends, Lakshmi and err…Lakshmi (Lachu and Deva).

We showed him around our flat and we introduced him to a little boy his age called…um, for my safety, I will not be mentioning his name, due to the unacceptable events that happened later!

My cousin has longish hair for a boy, so the little boy teased him that he looked like a girl. Unfortunately, I learnt the hard way that Pachu had a fly-away temper. He threw himself at the little boy and it looked like he nearly killed him from our point of view.

We saved the little boy from the wrath of my little cousin brother and we sent him back home for his own safety.

When we tried to take Pachu home, he played an annoying game of “tigers” and kept roaring at us and bit us whenever we crossed the 1-metre barrier.

We had no success and we were about to give up any chance that he would be budged from the bench he had made his fortress.

Then his head jerked up abruptly. We looked in his direction. There was a lovely red Porsche driving out through the gate. Pachu jumped up as if new life had surged through him and he ran behind the Porsche as if his life depended on it.

The Porsche drove out of the apartment and out onto the road.

I had always known he was mad about cars but this definitely took the cake.

The security guard shouted at him and we were scared to run out onto the street. I ventured out gingerly but there was no need for that.

A cat was chasing Pachu and he ran to us, curls flying, eyes bulging.

At last, the tiger had been overcome by a mere cat. I could see the headlines.

For some reason, we were overcome with a wave of hysteria and I grabbed Pachu’s wrist as we ran for home.

I was really mad at him but it is very hard to stay that way with him, so that was forgotten.

But the next incident, which happened recently, really could have ended him up in hospital.

We have moved to a new flat and so my uncle Manu, my aunty Priya and Pachu came to see it. I am very proud of my new bedroom, which has been painted according to the colour theme I wanted. The prize highlight is the 7-foot-tall bunk-bed which had always been my dream to own.

As expected, Pachu scrambled to the top as soon as he got the opportunity. I started playing with him and soon he got a crazy notion inside his head that I was going to whack him or something.

It was only a play and I told him so. He kept biting me and playing tiger again. I sighed.

I decided I had had enough of standing downstairs so I started climbing up the ladder to the top bunk.

I immediately regretted my decision. He said with a wild look in his eyes, “If you’re going to come up here, I will jump!” He positioned himself. Obviously, the words “seven-feet-tall” do not intimidate him.

I was grasped with fear. I was scared he’d actually do it. I wobbled a little on the ladder so I hoisted myself firmly onto a rung to keep my balance.

Big mistake.

He must have thought I was going to climb up and whack him or something, (I had absolutely no intention of even scratching, let alone whacking a poor, innocent little child like him) and he did something that made my heart stop.

He jumped.

I screamed.

Everyone ran towards my room and came to see Pachu lying on my floor, and Priya Aunty was almost in tears. Thankfully, he opened his eyes, shifted and groaned, “My leg…ouch…”

Miraculously, he had no broken bones at all, except for a few bruises here and there.

We all sighed in relief.

And I resolved never to be left alone with him again. If I could help it, that is. You never know what he’s going to get up to next.

mainheading: Searching for paradise
author: Khadeeja Jashim,
article:
Wandering all over the paradise
I asked them where the paradise was
They shook their head as if they didn't know
Leaving me alone in a sea of grief

I searched all over the land
And dived through all water bodies
To search for the great big paradise
Without realizing I am in paradise!!!

I heard a lot about paradise
So green with big big trees
Where we find love, kindness and humanity
And where our wishes come true

I left home in despair
I found hell in yesterday's paradise
The green paradise of earth
Has vanished by the cruelty of man

mainheading: The rhythm of 1001 hands for world peace
subheading: The students were trained for “Rhythm of 1k1 hands” by Imthiyas Aboobacker, the renowned choreographer in a bid for Guinness world record for the most number of hands coming together for finger dancing.
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
On Saturday, 500 students of Gregorian Public School, Maradu hit their fingers on the floor to display the unique art form of finger dancing in the rhythm of world peace and unity.

When the song Vande Mataram started playing inside the auditorium of the school, hands in green, white and orange colours started to move and take steps with the rhythm using their fingers. For next five minutes, it was a feast of music, rhythm and dance for the audience.

Named as “Rhythm of 1k1 hands” the students were trained by Imthiyas Aboobacker, the renowned choreographer, for two months. It was first of its kind in India and was also been a bid for Guinness world record for the most number of hands coming together for finger dancing.

The event was inaugurated by Joseph Mor Gregorios Metropolitan, while Sunila Sibi, Chairperson of Maradu Municipality and Jayaprabha Pradeep, Principal of Gregorian Public School spoke.

The finger dance was themed and choreographed as a message for world peace and harmony.

mainheading: Kochi Metro inaugurated by Prime Minister
author: Db Correspondent
article:
Prime Minister Narendra Modi inaugurated the much-awaited Kochi Metro on June 17 in a grand event at Kaloor stadium and opened the 13km first phase from Aluva to Palarivattom for public transportation. Thus Kochi becomes the first tier –II city to have a metro go for a commercial operation.

With the arrival of Metro, the transportation system of the city will be restructured with feeder services of buses and an ambitious 800 crore Water Metro.  The project was executed by Delhi Metro Rail Corporation and will be operated by Kochi Metro Rail Limited. Costing around Rs 6000 crore, the Metro has 26 km service with 22 stations, while the first phase has 13 km with 11 stations.

Kochi Metro Rail Ltd (KMRL) received the crucial safety certificate and inspection report from the Commissioner of Metro Rail Safety (CRMS) with considerable appreciation in May. The team of CRMS praised both the superiority of works and the theme-based stations built under KMRL.

After inspecting the 13.4 km section with 11 stations of the elevated rail corridor and the depot in Muttom, they compared the quality of work of KMRL as better than that of the making of Metros in Bangalore and Hyderabad. The inspection included tracks, trains, stations, fire alarms, CCTV, signalling, telecommunications and public information systems. 

The elevated corridor was also inspected by Pinarayi Vijayan, the chief minister of Kerala on June 04 prior to the visit of prime minister after which he launched the function of solar energy project at Aluva Metro station. He travelled a 13 km journey in the train along with Metro officials.

The Metro has appointed 39 loco pilots, all from Kerala, of which seven are women. Kochi Metro hired 23 transgender persons for the project and became the first government-owned company to do so.

Every station was designed to exhibit the artworks and images based on a unique theme. Passengers will have an exciting entry into the natural beauty of Kerala at Aluva station, while CUSAT station exhibits the maritime history of the state. Edappally station is celebrating the tradition of spices, coconut, tea and coffee made in the God’s Own Country, while the station at Nehru Stadium showcases the prideful moments of in state's sports heritage.

The stations will also display uplifting thoughts from both from Malayalam and International literature. Kochi was the first tier II city in India to get approval to have a metro rail in 2011. The metro service is expected to increase the speed of movements inside the city and decrease the number of vehicles with fewer traffic congestions. The next 5 km stretch from Palarivattom to Maharaja’s College is anticipated to begin its service from August 2017.

mainheading: City celebrates humour with CariToons Kochi 2017
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
With the second season of Caritoons Kochi 2017, Kochi celebrated the comic art forms from Ottanthullal to animated drawings and hilarious skits from May 4 to 8. Started in 2016 the cartoon and caricature festival organised by Kerala Cartoon Academy is intended to transform Kochi into the humour hub of Kerala.

In addition to lectures by cartoonists, caricaturists and animators of national eminence, the festival also showcased discussion and open sessions with cartoonists.

Exhibited in eight different venues of Kochi, the festival had separate sessions for children which included making cartoons, caricature and attending lectures. More than 200 children participated in making their favourite cartoon characters and learned from the eminent cartoonists, came from different parts of the country, about the art of drawing for humour with social responsibility.

mainheading: Why Peacocks flocking to city is not a good news for Kochi?
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
Bird watchers around Kochi are alerted with a few unusual visitors in the city’s biodiversity: Peacocks and White broad Bulbuls. The birds that can be only seen in dry climatic regions are now reportedly spotted in Edappaly and Kalamassery.

The visit is considered to be very uncommon and perhaps gives a message that Kochi is changing into dry climate. Especially, Peacocks were earlier only seen in dry places like Tamil Nadu, Chinnar, Wayanad and a few pockets in Palakkad.

The climate is changing, definitely, due to human irresponsibility and exploitation. It is impossible to deny that these changes also have adverse effects on the lives of animals, birds and plants. Many times there are proofs that animals do have superior abilities to recognise variations in weather.  

 

Though there is no scientific confirmation of this unusual presence, due to lack of data, the bird watchers confirm with uniformity that birds which can be spotted only in dry places are flocking to Kerala.

Vishnupriyan Kartha, Secretary, Cochin Natural History Society, said “It is impossible to predict a trend right now, as we don’t scientific data available. We have to wait until 2020 to confirm such trends identified by separate bird watchers. Because data collection both in individuals level and from CNHS are in a progressing stage. Still, the spotting of Peacocks and White broad Bulbuls in Edappaly and Kalamassery are unusual and shows the weather change in Kochi to a much drier climate.”

Since 2015, CNHS is working on an ambitious Kerala Birds Atlas Project to collect the details of birds that in the state and built a scientific database.

mainheading: The angry birds are back with a game to teach Physics
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
Whether you are still playing the Angry Birds or not, you know one thing for sure: how exciting it is to throw birds at the pigs to destroy their base and win. Now the same team which has created this excitement is back with a new game. This time to teach you physics with the same passion and greatness.

Big Bang Legends is a science-based game launched by a Finnish start-up ‘Lightnneer’ in March 2017 to help students in learning particle physics while having so much fun. The game involves solving puzzles and mazes to earn collectable rewards with 118 super-powered characters from the periodic table which makes the player familiar with their names, symbols and characteristics which students might have to learn in classrooms.

“Everything that happening in the game is actually based on science”, said Lauri Järvilehto, CEO, Lightneer.

Lightneer is a Finnish start-up by a team of gaming innovators who were previously working on Angry Birds, the most downloaded game in the history, for Rovio Entertainment.  Big bang Legends is their first project which brought together the brains of CERN and Oxford. The game integrates both casual and fun gameplay with educational content and particle physics.

Lauri Järvilehto, CEO of Lightneer says: “We want to make the playful and inclusive Finnish model accessible to everybody in the world to get great learning results through fun learning.” “Five years ago we’d joke that one day we’ll teach quantum physics to five-year-olds. Now we’re seeing five-year-olds playing Big Bang Legends and having conversations about quarks, protons and atoms. It’s pretty amazing.”

The company also revealed their plans to expand the brand from particle physics to building games about quantum physics, chemistry and even geography. The game can be only downloaded on Apple devices, but will soon be available on Android platforms too.

mainheading: Blue Whale: CBSE asks schools to supervise online activities of students
subheading: The circular directs to educate students, comply with legislation, take disciplinary actions and install surveillance systems.
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
While Blue Whale Challenge, the online suicidal game is creating a hoax in the country, Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) has produced a circular on August 18 to promote safe and secure educational environment in schools by taking measures to pre-empt wrongful activities through IT-enabled devices in schools. 

The circular says “Increasing proliferation and sophistication of various electronic devices makes it all the more obligatory for schools to control and monitor their use by students.”

Educate:

The circular directs to create awareness among students regarding the safe and effective internet usage and display rules on the acceptable use.

Comply with legislation:

CBSE has asked schools to comply with the legislation of copyright, theft, discrimination and obscenity in devices and only use a licensed version of the software in them. It has also asked institutions to draft a policy on this matter and implement it.

Take strict actions:

The guidelines urge to take strict disciplinary actions against those violate norms and access inappropriate or illegal materials on the internet using devices in school.

Deploy surveillance system

The circular asks to install firewalls, filtering and monitoring software mechanisms and review blocking policies of unwelcomed contents. Students should be using the internet in visible areas and only allowed to access pre-selected websites.

The circular reads “if children use the internet without safety awareness, they may fall prey to illegal activity or abuse such as cyberbullying, fraud or something even more serious. Hence, awareness of internet safety norms is absolutely indispensable to make children free to explore knowledge without feeling intimidated.”

mainheading: Prosperity Index: Kochi declared smartest among smart cities in India
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
Among the first 20 smart cities announced, Kochi comes first in the prosperity index study done by National Institute of Urban Affairs (NIUA), way above the national capital. The study titled 'Multi-dimensional prosperity index(MPI): Review of the first 20 cities of India' was published on the behalf of Asian Development Bank and was released on August 5. 

MPI is the new index introduced to examine the developments of smart cities which comprise of four indicators in itself such as (1)physical and financial infrastructure index, (2)health and educational infrastructure index, (3)community asset index and (4)household amenities index. 

Though the study showcases the impressive developments in the city, thanks to the all-new Kochi Metro, the report also highlights the challenges faced by the metropolitan on the way to become a true 'Smart city'. This also provides suggestions and guidelines for the way ahead.

The report sights the bright side of Kochi as  

1. High literacy rate

2. Low slum population

3. High percentage of households with tap water, toilet facilities and electricity

4. Availability of health, financial and educational institutions

The challenges were listed as

1. Inadequate transport and parking infrastructure

2. only a few areas in the city are linked by sewerage network,

3. polluted water bodies,

4. shortage of open spaces

5. shortage of land for new projects

The strategies included

1. Connect Fort Kochi and the central city through an integrated water transport project.

2. Uplift the central city area through redensification.

3. Harness the heritage assets of Fort Kochi and Mattancherry for tourism.

4. Create new housing stock in Mattancherry.

5. Upgrade the basic infrastructure.

6. Augment the canal system.

7. Ensure 24x7 water supply services

Read full report here: https://khub.niua.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/multi_dimensional.pdf

mainheading: World Peace Day: Remembering the girl who stood between the nuclear bombs
subheading: Every year, 21 September is observed as the International Day of Peace around the globe. This year, United Nations honours the spirit of TOGETHER, a global initiative that promotes respect, safety and dignity for everyone forced to flee their homes in search of peace.
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
In 1982, the cold war between the United States of America and Soviet Union (USSR) reached its peak, when Yuri Andropov became the general secretary of Communist party of Soviet Union. Everyone was discussing a possible breakout of war between the two countries and most importantly a chance for the nuclear attack was in the air.

It was then Samantha Smith; a 10-year-old schoolgirl from Manchester, USA wrote a letter to Andropov about her worries on a potential nuclear war and urged him to live together in peace.

On April 26, 1983, Yuri Andropov wrote back to Samantha by assuring that he is doing everything so that war will not break out and also invited her to visit USSR. She with her parents flew to Moscow and spent two weeks of that summer visiting children’s camp near Black sea, attending conferences and making friends.

She later wrote in her book that she was surprised by the kind of friendliness of Soviet people and the gifts they brought.

She became a sudden sensation not just in the US and the Soviet Union but also around the world as a symbol of peace. Samantha also became to known as "America's Youngest Ambassador" for her peacemaking activities in Japan, before she died at the age of 13 in a plane crash.

Do you know: The Soviet government issued a postage stamp with her face and named a diamond and an asteroid in her honour.

mainheading: 27,848 students get tech training in Kerala to lead digital education
subheading: ‘Hi School Kuttikuttam’ is an NCC-model student’s IT club started in 2016 at all government-aided schools to equip them with 3-year technological training and thus to maintain, monitor and secure the Hi-tech facilities used in their classrooms.
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
Kerala Infrastructure and Technology for Education (KITE), previously known as IT@School, under the Education Department of Kerala, organised e@Utsav, 2-day training camps, for two batches of ‘Kuttikuttam’ divided into five specific groups of animation, cybersecurity and the internet, electronics, hardware and Malayalam computing between September 7 and 10.

The camp held at 1368 centres across the state gave training to 27,848 student members of ‘tech-army’ with 2736 trained faculty during this vacation. The project aims to let students discover their hidden talents by giving 2-year continues training and a project submission which will enable them to monitor the technological facilities provided by the government to elevate the status of classrooms to Hi-tech.

Saju S S, master trainer, academic division, KITE, said: “The member students of the club are the ambassadors of KITE who will maintain, monitor and secure the Hi-tech classrooms and disseminate the knowledge that they have received to other students thus benefitting all.”

In the academic year of 2016-17, KITE, which paves the way for Hi-tech education in the state, initiated to build a network of one lakh tech-trained students army to maintain and monitor the 45000 Hi-tech classrooms of 2000 government-aided schools. The government is providing schools with interactive boards, laptops, speaker systems and projectors to elevate the status of classrooms to Hi-tech,  but only to those completed the criteria of getting basic facilities like tiled floors, concrete roofing, and whitewashing was done.

Jayadevan C S, the Ernakulam district coordinator, KITE, said: “Globally, this is for the first time that a selected group of students are trained in such diverse technological sectors. For a high school student who joined ‘Kuttikuttam’ while studying in 8th standard, the training will continue for 3 years and will be the custodians of all Hi-tech classrooms in the state. The project also targets to make students realize the hidden talents that they have in themselves.”

“The training is also connected to start-ups, Technopark, Infopark and even with the companies like Google which are already scheduled. The Code to Learn contest of Google had the most number of students registered from ‘Kuttikuttam’”, he said.

Membership to the club is provided only after rigorous tests and is constrained to 12% of the total population of high school students or 50, whichever is less, in a particular school.

mainheading: With more passengers and extended services, Kochi Metro is gearing up
author: Db Correspondent
article:
On Tuesday, the second section of Kochi Metro’s first phase was inaugurated by Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan along with the presence of Hardeep Singh Puri, Union Minister for Housing & urban affairs. The extended service adds 5kms and 5 new stations of JLN Stadium, Kaloor, Lissie, MG Road and Maharajas ground.

The extension has made a considerable increase in the ridership of Kochi Metro as it now connects with the business centre of Kochi and is expected to decrease the traffic congestions at Kaloor, Deshabhimani and Kacherippady junctions.

It is estimated that an average of 30,000 passengers travel on metro every day with Sundays and holidays having more collection on which days the metro runs in increased frequency of trains.

During the inauguration ceremony, Chief minister confirmed that the govt will ensure the economic feasibility of metro which reflects the concern that metro is not getting enough ridership due to high ticket charges. The metro service may also introduce a monthly card and a full-day ticket system in subsidised rates to attract more commuters though the fares are not confirmed yet.

With the feeder services planned towards an integrated transportation system which is expected to the traffic pressure on the swiftly growing city of Kochi. KMRL is also considering the second and third extensions from Palarivattom to Kakkand and from Aluva to Angamaly with possible stations at Nedumbassery Airport after completing the first phase till Thrippunithura.

mainheading: How St. Albert's HSS is helping to radicalise reading in other schools?
subheading: "Book on Wheels" is an ambitious project kickstarted by St. Albert's HSS to pool books, rejuvenate economically disadvantaged school libraries and innovate the concept of library outside its four walls.
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
In a mission to reach out to economically backward schools, on Monday, the students of St. Albert's HSS gifted as much as 1200 books, collected by themselves, to eight different schools outside the metropolitan limits of Kochi. The management and the students are now engaged in a mission to pool books on a large scale to help renovate libraries both inside and outside the school throughout this academic year.

"Book on Wheels", as it is named, has got inaugurated by Fr. Felix Chullikal, general manager, St Albert's HSS by handing over a collection of books to students and teachers of St. Mary's LP School, Ponnarimangalam.

"It is very important to have libraries and encourage students to read which will not only help them in academics but also in creating a better future. Let me appreciate all those students who have contributed books to this mission to help students read and grow", he said. 

The school is also building shelves in its corridors to catch the eyes of students towards books and encourage them to read. Particularly, reference books are taken out of the library to reach where students are and making them comfortable with it. To build the culture, teachers encourage students to bring books and donate them to the library instead of chocolates and food items during special occasions. 

The management has shown their enthusiasm to continue the project for coming years and help more students to read. 

Baby Thadevus Cruz, Principal, St. Albert’s HSS said, “We are planning to continue the project along with the renovation of our library throughout the academic year. We also want to help other schools also in restructuring their libraries and refocus their ideas on books. We are in a need to help our younger generations find their way back to books and reading.”

mainheading: U-17 World Cup: Football is in the Indian court while the world is gazing
subheading: 24 national teams from six confederations are playing at six stadiums in different cities around the country, while 187 countries across the globe are watching.
author: Db Correspondent
article:
With the first ever Indian appearance in a football world cup, 2017 FIFA U-17 world cup, the first FIFA tournament in the country, has kick-started at Jawaharlal Nehru Stadium, Delhi on 06 October. With the final to be played on 28 October at Salt Lake stadium, Kolkata, the 22-day tournament is all set to awaken the "sleeping giant", as FIFA called India, to the glamour of the world's most popular game. 

Kochi

As one of the most important host venue for the tournament among the six cities, Kochi is well placed to exhibit its football-crazy fan base and the tourism potential in front of the world. The government of Kerala had spent at least 17 crores before the arrival of the world cup and beautified the city with better roads, beautiful practice grounds and improved sports facilities. 

Kochi metro started its final section of the first phase just 2 days before the tournament, which includes JLN stadium station to ease the transportation inside the city, while the authorities have installed strict traffic regulations in Kochi. 

Brazil vs Spain

It was with great excitement Kochi celebrated the victory of Brazil over Spaniards for 2-1 in a much-awaited match in Kochi. Even after FIFA brought down the seating capacity to 29,000 from the original 60,000 due to security reasons. 

India vs the USA

The much stronger team of USA defeated India for 3-0 in a match which saw the first Indian appearance in the world cup but also won hearts of Indian fans with strong gameplay throughout the match. 

24 teams managed to qualify for the tournament through various continental tournaments. The first round of the tournament will see teams competing in round-robin groups of four teams, with the top two teams in each group moving on while the top four third-placed teams will also move forward. These 16 teams will compete in the knockout stage, where three rounds of play will resolve which teams would join in the final.

mainheading: National Sports Day: Remembering the hockey legend; Dhyan Chand
subheading: Every year India observes it's National Sports Day on August 29 which is also the birth anniversary of legendary hockey player Major Dhyan Chand.
author: Db Correspondent
article:
We celebrate the National Sports day on his birthday on August 29, Dhyan Chand is one of the greatest hockey players of all the time. Nicknamed as ‘The Wizard’, he was a wonder-man with a stick for many of his times because of his phenomenal goal scoring abilities and the control over the ball, scoring over 400 goals in international Hockey. He played a crucial role when India won three consecutive Olympic gold medals in 1928, 1932 and 1936.

The officials of Netherlands Hockey once broke the stick used by Dhyan Chand to check if he was using a magnet to keep the ball with it. To admire his importance, the hockey lovers of Austria made a statue of Dhyan Chand with four hands and four sticks to honour his abilities to control the ball. In the heights of his glory, the German Chancellor Adolf Hitler was impressed by Dhyan Chand and offered him German citizenship and the rank of colonel in the army, which he denied politely.

mainheading: 6 students from Ernakulam to compete in National Robotics Championship
subheading: With the robots that showcase the sustainable way of living, two teams trained under DCS Robotics Academy in Aluva and Panampilly Nagar are travelling to New Delhi today.
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
Two teams of three students each, from Ernakulam district, is participating in ‘Sustainabots’, the national robotics championship organised by the ‘India Stem Foundation’ in New Delhi on 7 & 8 October. The competition regarded as the selection process to the ‘World Robot Olympiad’ that to be held in Costa Rica in November this year has kept sustainable tourism as the theme.

The first team participating in the regular competition of elementary stage had gone through a state level selection process held at Trivandrum and had won the second place. The much younger second team is participating in the open challenge competition of elementary stage and had no selection process but a direct access to the game. 

Lincy Jexy, chief instructor, DCS Robotics, said “It is with confidence and skill our students are participating in the competition. Both the regular category and open challenge are ready with their maps, robots, equipment and software. The trainers and students will use Saturday to prepare all the stuff for contest according to the space provided there as Sunday will be the final day of competition.” 

“Robotics is a space where students can practically learn the subjects that they have dealt with in their classroom rooms, particularly Physics and Mathematics. Though with great scope, robotics get very less support from our state and in form of sponsorships. Whereas many other states and the governments have understood the importance and encourage both materially and financially” she said.

The regular category has a strict format and pre-designed map based on the theme, while the open challenge is a competition designed to encourage innovation and the use of imagination in the field of robotics using the same theme. 

The Regular Elementry

Aybaq Zyed (5th standard), Gautham Krishna (7th) and Vishnu P Venmony (7th) are trained by DCS Robotics Academy in Aluva to use the robots and ‘Mindstorm EV3’ software to control the pre-designed map that represents a landscape with oceans, rainforest areas and roads with characters such as jaguars, turtles, civilians and scientists waiting to get placed in their location. The task of the robot is to rearrange the characters inside the landscape by pushing jaguar to forest and turtles to water bodies while leaving civilians and scientists only at safe places. 

While the state level competition was to complete the task within the time frame of two minutes, the national level is about completing the same task in the least time, where more than 100 teams are participating from different parts of the country. 

The Open Challenge

 The competition that demands innovation and the use of imagination, Nanak Johan Varghese (4th), Rachel Aji Joseph (6th) and Abhiram Rajesh (6th) have built a 'Sustainable city' on their table controlled by robots. The city uses automatically moving solar panels with the movement of the sun, which may improve its efficiency by 35%. The urban centre separates its waste into the material, degradable and plastic using a sorting factory of Infrared and colour sensors. 

 While the material wastes are recycled and degradable are used in farming, the plastic wastes are sent to a power station to generate electricity by burning it. Using the sensors, the city could also identify the excess amount of carbon dioxide (co2) in its atmosphere and push them to a forest nearby.  

 DCS Robotics operates their academy in Aluva and Panampilly Nagar with more than 100 hundred children learn the aspects of robot technology. The institute already has won prizes at Roboray competition held in China last year.

mainheading: It’s not just avoiding the plastic, but also to bring back the old culture
subheading: The Daybreak talks to Mohammed Safirulla IAS, District Collector, Ernakulam
author: Lakshmi Omanakuttan
article:
Pre-civil service experience and the IT Mission

I worked in IT for 5 years with TCS and IBM. In TCS I worked as an engineer where I was an associate for software building, coding, development and to some extent testing also and at IBM I was SAP  financial control consultant. As far as the project management of IT mission was concerned the previous experience in IT sector was definitely helpful. Moreover, IT mission’s profile is not only general administration but its techno-managerial role. Without understanding technology, you can’t manage it effectively as hardcore technology is involved in it. The experience in the IT field helped a lot in developing new technology projects like cloud implementation in servers, integration of database etc.

2.       Working with the common man

Unless we know the real issue faced by the people we can’t make effective policy for them. We should reach out to the people to understand their issue.  To get the feedback on policies made and implemented we have to be in close connection with the people for whom the policies are made other than just sitting in the living room and making policies. Many of the times the projects fail because it’s only made theoretically not practically.

 For instance, the 100-pound renovation in 50 days project is basically touching the pulse of the people; I have myself worked close to 65 pounds.  Another example is E Jagratha, a project for the cybersecurity, which included nearly 240 schools in the district with continuous interaction with the teachers and students and the school about developments in the project and interactive training section from experts from TCS. The perspective of an 8th standard student from a government school will be different from the perspective of an IAS officer or IT professional. To understand the perspective of the people we have to go to them. End beneficiary link and the continuous feedback loop are very important otherwise it might not actually succeed.

3.       Creating  a safe cyber platform for children

E-jagratha is an initiative to establish basic IT infrastructure and internet connectivity in schools and empower the students from different school background. It aims at preventing children from falling prey to predators in the internet world. E-jagaratha is also a tool to create awareness about the online transactions like e-billing, online purchasing etc. and to digitally empower schools students.

As the cyber world is expanding that the information and the entertainments that it provides are very vast. Therefore the new generation needs to be guided on a different aspect to use the internet safely and effectively. Nearly 240 schools have covered under this project now. Students and teachers from the schools are being selected to undergo training in this regard.

Quality implementation in the digital platform is one aspect of the project while reminding the students about their duties and responsibilities in the cyber world.

Another aim is to make them aware of the need for responsible use of the social media platform. Parents & teacher's associations are also involved in the program. Aided schools and CBSE schools are also considered in the program.

4.       Green protocol to bring back the old habits.

Like other states in India, Kerala does not have unused land or uninhabited land. The population is spread across the state and there for the waste disposal is very difficult. Due to the difficulty in effective waste disposal, there is a need for effective waste management. For this reason, the city administration in association with Haritha Kerala Mission has initiated green protocol in the district. As part of this, events are conducted which was fully based on green protocol.  It’s not just avoiding the plastic but also to bring back the old culture of using the nature-friendly utensils. The approach the public is very positive towards this mission. Awareness classes are also given in different level of the administration about the need for green protocol.

5.       For a successful career

There is no career which is bad. Every job is a good job. First of all, to have a successful career you have to love your career. Understand what you are capable of doing and work for it. One must work to find out what is your interest and develop your interest in your career. Only when you are interested in your job you can do justice to the work.

mainheading: Create a greener nature for next generation
subheading: Leena George talks to ‘The Daybreak’ about her illness and how crafting and gardening healed her. The 64-year-old transformed her land around home into a mirage of greenery and celebrates an eco-friendly existence in Kochi metropolitan.
author: Lakshmi Omanakuttan
article:
When passion heals

I was passionate about plants and gardening from my younger age. My hobby and passion have created a phenomenal change in me. A year ago I suffered a nervous breakdown and I was bedridden. At this age, it was very difficult to overcome stress and mental depression. To help it out I started off my crafting hobby and gardening. These activities healed me and gave self-confidence that I am capable of doing anything of my interest. They tuned my mind and motivated me to carry on my passions.  

The natural way of living

Recycling and upcycling are the best ways to have an effective healthy life because trash disposal is one of the major problems that we face today. Following a specific pattern for recycling and upcycling can reduce the amount of trash we have. I recycle most of the waste materials at my home by crafting it into a beautiful home decor or a garden utensil. No plastics are used for my creative works or in the garden. All the pots are eco-friendly, while the composts are made by natural methods like biogas, vermin and bin composts here itself.

Nurturing the habit of green

The habit of farming or gardening must be started from the school level as this can help in creating a greener nature for next generation rather than of plastic. Gardening will help to build a meaningful relationship between life and nature. In schools, this can be a part of extracurricular activities, projects and assignments. The children will understand the process of plant development; with which the students will be able to evaluate the importance of life in every living being.

It is important to teach the next generation how to manage the nature and the life with it. The only healthy way of farming is organic. Use of pesticides and insecticides are widely seen in the present agricultural industry and the vegetables we buy from the markets are mostly contaminated. All my plants have a yellow tag with applied Neem oil so that the insects are attracted to it and will not damage the plant.

Role of schools and parents

Waste management or trash disposal should be a part of our behaviour for which the schools and parents can play a vital role. The children should be trained about how to dispose the waste and should be taught how to maintain the public place clean. From their tender age itself, the habit of leaving the waste into a dustbin instead of throwing it in roads or public places should be inculcated as a culture.

Filtering and reusing water

The technique of aquaponics is used for filtering the fish tank water. Water from the fish tank will be pumped into a tub with plants, stones and other filtering substances. The excreta of fish is used as a fertiliser for plants; whereas the water gets filtered and flows back to the fish tank.

Upcycling

When it comes to pampering the nature; I believe in using only nature-friendly substances like stones, bamboo stakes, old broken woods etc. Water retaining is an important matter in maintaining the garden and for this, I have used the small stones for making paths. Upcycling old substances like coconut shell into pots, broken pieces of cartwheel into name board and use of old glass jars for close terrarium etc. helps to keep the garden more eco-friendly.

Keeping the public property clean

The major problem in our country is that people are very insensitive of their trash. They are worried only about disposing of their household waste from their area or vicinity and are least bothered about whether it’s thrown to another’s property. Even the educationally qualified does not think about maintaining the public property or the neighbour’s land.

From trash to living rooms

The majority of the raw materials I use for crafting are trash, but I recycle it by giving a creative touch and make it worth to be placed in our living rooms. I try to avoid plastics for my crafts as much as possible because I believe in eco-friendly living. To add more, we use solar power instead of electricity.

It’s not gardening or crafting will help you relax but it’s the interest of the individual that help. For everyone, the passion and hobbies differ and one must know what their interest is and should work on it.

mainheading: A life dedicated to the differently abled children of Kerala
imgtext: Mary Anitha, founder, 'Centre for Empowerment and Enrichment'
subheading: Mary Anitha, the founder of 'Centre for Empowerment and Enrichment' (CEFEE), is a socially committed visionary who indulges herself in supporting differently abled children in Kerala for their psychological well-being.  The institution conducts several public events throughout the year to bring these children together and thus back to the public domain. Excerpts from an interview with Libin Chacko Kurian.
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
Can you introduce us to how these works started?

I always had an inner calling to work for the downtrodden communities in our society. It was the differently abled children that I found heavily disadvantaged and started to serve them from 2011 with the inception of CEFEE. While studying in Hyderabad I had such experiences in social works, which may have intrigued me to do such works. 

Why we really need an institution for differently abled children?

Though the central government does have a department for the persons with disabilities, the state government of Kerala doesn't have a separate body, but only under the social justice department with many other sections take care of disabled. Differently abled children are often left unnoticed and are disadvantaged during the allocation of funds due to several such reasons.

In our programs, we minimize the number of speeches and keep an extra vigil to indulge with them because what they need the most is the love to remove the rejections that they have faced in their life. You won't often see differently-abled children on streets and are kept out of public spaces, which shouldn’t make them foreign to democratic rights. They are in real need for a community to bring them under a single umbrella while the blind already had such federations in both central and state level.

Can you define the ‘differently abled’ children that you deal with?

By children, I don't mean under-18 because their mental age may differ from that of the physical age. So, when I say children this may also include a person of physical age 45 and his mental age could be around 8-9. The differently abled is a large spectrum of several categories which may include cerebral palsy, mental retardation, orthopaedic disabilities, deaf, dump or with multiple disabilities.

What are the problems faced by these children?

The whole category of differently abled children is grown with very a low self-esteem and they find themselves in a difficult state to build confidence from a very young age. The first rejection came from their own parents, who cannot accept the condition into which their children are born into. Of course, parents do have their own expectation about how their children may look like or what he may do or even about what he should become. Often such parents may end up in taking care of their children without accepting the disabilities he does have which may cause severe psychological implications on children.

The golden thousand days

Only if the parent accepts the fact of disability, the door of treatment opens before their children. But parents often use a defensive mechanism to reject this fact and in a way, deny several treatments that the child should be receiving. If you can start treatment on the first thousand days of a child, when most of the disabilities can be identified, many disabilities like body distortions or brain damage can be reverted. From that point of time, if parents can start treatments with an acknowledgement that his child is different, we can make him grow into a comparatively normal condition.

Physical rejections

Many times children with disabilities are grown with rejections in different parts of their life and he will revert it back to the society. Even a normal kid would have done the same, but a child with disabilities also have a potential to get violent in such situations. He will not be able to accept the people around. Due to such behaviours, parents often lock them inside a house and would never consider taking him outside. They are heavily separated from the mainstream society.

A problem with the wealthy

Children with disabilities born to wealthy parents also face some peculiar challenges. Such children are often gifted with advanced infrastructure facilities, drivers, and servants while denying love, which they desperately need. They want to communicate, meet more people and travel which we often reject them from. They are often tried to fix into routine or system which they may refuse to accept violently.

Psychological rejections

Most of the problems that differently abled children face are rooted from the psychological rejections they face rather than the physical ones. The things we speak have a definite influence on these children and it amplifies the problems. 

The government

The government of Kerala is educating 20 lakh ‘so-called’ normal children in their schools whereas 8.5 lakh differently abled children are left with no consideration. On 14 November during the celebrations of Children’s day, the government gives them a treat provided with milk and banana, but through all these years and with all these schools they are never been invited to be educated.

mainheading: Chief Minister officially launched Responsible tourism mission
subheading: 1.5 lakh jobs to be created under responsible tourism. The inauguration ceremony followed strict Green Protocol norms
author: Db Correspondent
article:
The Responsible Tourism initiatives in the state woke up to a new dawn, with the Chief Minister, Shri Pinarayi Vijayan launching the dedicated Mission for it. The world's first Responsible Tourism Mission is all set to lead Kerala Tourism through people-friendly, local community-friendly and environment-friendly, initiatives ensuring rural development, employment opportunities and women empowerment.

Sri Kadakampally Surendran, Minister of Tourism, presided over the function. Sri K Suresh Kurup MLA and Shri Jose K Mani were the chief guests of the function. Dr Venu V, IAS, Principal Secretary, Kerala tourism delivered the welcome speech and P Bala Kiran, IAS, Director of Tourism presented the Responsible Tourism Mission project. Sri K Rupesh Kumar, coordinator, State Responsible Tourism Mission announced the new Responsible tourism destinations.

Welcoming the gathering, Dr Venu V IAS Principal Secretary Kerala Tourism said that It’s a proud moment for all of us. Responsible Tourism that started off in Kumarakom is now a world-renowned concept and a point of discussion across the globe. It’s definitely a proud moment for us to be a pioneer in setting up this concept so effectively. Within a span of 9 years, 16 crores is the profit Kumarakom could gain through tourism. Around 1.16 crore revenue is generated by the localities. The reason behind this growth is the involvement as a group by the communities around. The aim of RT is to create 1.5 lakh jobs in the future, said Dr Venu V.

Presiding over the function, Sri Kadakampally Surendran, Honorable Minister of Tourism, said, to be the pioneer state in practising the concept of Responsible Tourism in the entire country is a proud moment. The government policy is to make Tourism more popular. Apart from improving the functioning of the elite class, the government also aims to use tourism as a tool for village development and women empowerment. Their aim is to make Responsible Tourism more beneficial to the localities. It feels proud to see the mission that started off in Kumarakom as a pilot project in 2008 and is very happy and proud about this. The Government moves forward aiming to bring in more job opportunities and income generation to the localities”

Inaugurating the Responsible Tourism Mission of the state, Speaking on the occasion, Honorable Chief Minister- Pinarayi Vijayan said, “Waste management should be a prime consideration in any development program. The tourist spots and places around the state should be kept clean at all times without asking for an additional cost. It should be a practice by itself. The tourism department should make enough arrangements to accommodate than the number of tourists coming into the state. One needs to appreciate Responsible Tourism completely for it is a source of support for the local communities. Our land is encompassed by serenity and greenery. That is why it's called God’s own country. Hence, more attention given to Tourism wing will only prove to be beneficial for the development of the state. There are a lot of countries around the world who has made the profit through tourism. Hence, the same level of importance should be given here. The people who come in as tourists are financially sound in many ways. However, it's not the financially sound people who walk in as tourists, there are a lot of people within our state who are tourists. Most of the tourists in our state are largely common and middle-class people. However, these people who hail from our state as tourists should not be exploited said Honorable Chief Minister Sri Pinarayi Vijayan. However, in today’s world, mentalities and approaches have changed slowly.  People abroad buy products from the manufacturing place itself thereby paying huge amounts for it. Hence, in order to sell these products, we have to ensure proper arrangements. We have to consider these tourists as our guests and we have to treat them well off and for this, the society will have to pay attention and equally contribute to this development. 

With a bunch of new projects under the new mission, the state aims at expanding Responsible Tourism across the state by incorporating a set of new destinations. Currently, it is carried out only in seven destinations in the state, viz. Kumarakom, Thekkady, Vythiri, Ambalavayal, Kumbalangi, Bakel and Kovalam. Kerala has bagged countless national and international awards and recognition for these projects. Sri Kadakampally Surendran, Minister for Tourism, Government of Kerala, bagged six National Tourism Awards 2015-16 from The President Shri Ram Nath Kovind, Vigyan Bhawan in New Delhi out of which one was credited for the Best Responsible Tourism Initiative for ‘Kumarakom’.

Shri P Bala Kiran IAS, Director of Kerala Tourism gave a deep insight into the Responsible Tourism mission project. 1”4 districts across the state have initiated Responsible Tourism cells. The state RT cell has been formed and has already kick-started with its functioning and as part of this, from 6 destinations, today we have almost 35 destinations on RT across Kerala", said Bala Kiran IAS, Director of Tourism, Kerala.

Turning these baby steps into big leaps, the Mission takes Responsible Tourism to all 14 districts. The government plans to create 1,50,000 employment opportunities in the tourism sector alone through the Responsible Tourism Mission, in a span of 5 years. The selected destinations for the Responsible Tourism plan are mostly areas that are covered by backwater, sea, wildlife, heritage and diversity in areas comprising natural beauty. The scheme is being implemented with the primary objective of ensuring extra income and livelihood for agricultural labourers, traditional industrial workers and marginalized communities in these areas and to give equal importance to the social-environmental parity.

Vocational training will be provided to at least 50,000 local natives.  This year, as a part of Responsible Tourism, at least 20 Village Life Experience Packages will be opened. It has been proven that Village tourism packages attract a lot of tourists because of the conventional experience of rope-making, handloom, earthenware and toddy tapping in these packages. This project will take the responsibility of ensuring more ways of income to the local community by means of keeping traditional jobs, handicraft activities and classical art forms as part of tourism. The next 4 years will focus on the formation of widespread workshops, tourism planning with popular participation and much more.

mainheading: Learn the law that safeguards children from physical attacks
subheading: The section 75 of juvenile justice act protects children from being assaulted in any kind.
author: Lakshmi Omanakuttan
article:
On May 23, Kochi city police arrested Mini Mathew, aged 49 years, from a daycare center near Palarivattam, under section 75 of juvenile justice act and of IPC section 323 for assaulting a year and half old boy who was dropped off to the institution by his parents in the morning.

The incident came to light when a video footage of the event, shot on a mobile camera by another woman employee was telecasted in a television channel. The Victim’s parents lodged a complaint to the Kochi city police and Childline volunteers. Kochi Mayor Soumini Jain visited the institution and inspected the facilities and enquired about the incident.

Sec. 75 of juvenile justice act say that if any person who has control over or charge of the child does anything that can cause mental or physical suffering to the child, he or she shall be punished with imprisonment or fine or both.

If such act is done by biological parents of the child due to any uncontrollable circumstances, it is not punishable. Whereas if such an act is done by any person who is employed or managing an organization which is assigned to the duty of care and protection of the child and causes any mental or physical illness, then he or she shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment not less than 3 years which may extend to 10 year and fine of Rs 5 lakhs.

IPC Sec 323 explains that if any person voluntarily causes hurt to another without any provocation shall be punished with imprisonment up to 1 year or with fine up to Rs 1000 or with both.

mainheading: Celebrate this Onam with the values and traditions we own
subheading: 'The Daybreak' is looking back into all these Onam celebrations we had and reviewing its effect on the students who do it.
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
Yet another Onam is here and that’s the festive season of Kerala. Most of the schools are preparing for an Onam celebration at the end of this month after all the exams are over. The students will leave for a short vacation as the month of September arrives.

For all these years Onam and the culture have become the crucial part of school affairs and had a definite impact on the student life. In a recent development, the state Higher Secondary Directorate had to reschedule the exams in order to allow the students have Onam celebrations with other students.

This year most of the schools have scheduled their celebrations on August 31 as it is the last day before vacation and the only day left after exams. The beautiful floral arrangements of Pookalam, the traditionally dressed King Mahabali, the dance forms of Thiruvathira and other competitions are set to rock the schools this season.

Breaks all identities

Unlike other festivals, which are religious and are confined to a particular religion, Onam has become the cultural identity of people in the state, while destroying all divisions.

Though the legends and rituals belong to a single religion, the celebrations and cultural developments have crossed all boundaries of identifications. Schools and the celebrations they conduct had played a crucial role creating the secular face of Onam by encouraging students to breaks all such divisions among them.

Thus Onam has also become the secular identity of our state.

Builds teams

Unlike any other festivals, Onam definitely demands a sense of teamwork among. Many of the schools have the Pookalam or the flower arrangements as their single biggest attraction. While some schools also have competitions among the classes for best arrangements.

In any of these situations, a collaborative work of both students and teachers are required, which in-turn develops team sense and builds strong bonds among.

This involves collecting beautiful flowers of different colours, designing the arrangements and making it into a circular arrangement of colours. The dance form Thiruvathira or competition items like Tug of war all require a great deal of teamwork.

Thus Onam also makes students work in a group.

Sharing is caring

As the harvest festival, the celebrations of Onam have a great importance for the food or the Onam Sadya. Many schools had created a norm to have an Onam Sadya with both students and teachers which developed the sense of sharing.

The Sadya always have the traditional nine plus vegetarian meal that we traditionally follow. To have the same food on this day has brought the sense of sharing and caring. The schools have a definite role in pushing them.

The costumes

Onam is never complete without the King Mahabali. Most of the schools have the arrangement for a traditionally dressed king-like figure to reach every student in the school. This is a reminder for the story and values he shares. Thus the celebrations of Onam also involve wearing the traditional dress. Beyond the Dhoti and saree, students are exposed to the Onam games which give a colourful twist into the costume diversity of Kerala.

The music and dance also take students to the rich antiquity of this state and makes it a traditional feast for children.

mainheading: The South Indian declaration of independence from filth
subheading: On the Independence Day of 15 August 2017, the Govt. of Kerala initiated a campaign, 'Freedom from waste', to make Kerala free from waste with much hype and glamour.  Beyond the declarations and pledges, The Daybreak is digging deep into the world of wast
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
Pinarayi Vijayan, the chief minister of Kerala, in a recent video conference with district collectors in the state pointed out that there has been 'no' or 'a very little' improvement in the state of waste management in cities and must look forward to a mandatory centralised processing plant in every urban centre. He emphasised the importance of using both centralised and decentralised methods of waste management systems as the latter is not giving expects results in the state. He also asked to speed up the process of land identification and acquisition suitable for these plants. 

The words of chief minister clearly reflect the concerns and dilemmas we today face with respect to the ever piling up filth around us. 

Why fear waste?

Waste is everywhere in different forms and types. From households to industrial factories, from farmlands to markets and from computers to internet all produce the left behind stuff. Be it in solid/liquid/gaseous form or divided as organic and non-organic, the fact of waste has become a crucial part of our everyday life. 

We use several mechanisms to get rid of these waste materials using the traditional methods of landfills or combustion or else by dumping them into water sources. 

Landfills or by burying the solid and liquid waste under the soil, we may cause severe contamination of air and water. Lack of space has also become a factor in discouraging this common but traditional method of waste management. 

Combustion of solid waste also creates pollution in air, water and soil as it has to come back to like Newton's apple. The burning in high temperatures and conversion of waste into residue and gaseous products also create life-threatening poisonous elements as shown in research. 

Throwing waste materials into water sources is one of the old method employed to get rid of filth when no other place is available which heavily contaminates the water resources. 

Pollution caused by the traditional methods of waste management results in dangerous public health implications. Govt. of Kerala confirms that at least 22 diseases common in the state are caused due to improper waste management. Contamination of water resources makes the state more vulnerable to the water-borne diseases. 

Freedom from waste

Along with the Independence Day celebrations of this year, the government of Kerala introduced an ambitious but a herculean task to make the state free of waste. Freedom from waste is a campaign based on comprehensive action plan jointly led by Suchitwa mission and Haritha Keralam mission to process garbage at their sources like households, gated colonies, markets and industrial units in a decentralised method. The local bodies are held responsible for the implementations and ensure the community participation from grass root level. 

Ordinance to stop throwing waste into water sources

In a recent development, an ordinance was produced by the state government against dumping garbage or any other form of waste into water sources may now attract a jail term of two years and a fine up to Rs 3 lakh. 

E-waste from schools

Schools, colleges and educational institutions play a huge role in creating electronic wastes, which may release heavily poisonous substances into nature and cause severe contaminations. So, it is of paramount importance to make sure the scientific disposal of e-waste. For last two decades, schools are using several types of equipment in their labs to teach children, but wonder about what to do with those left behind. 

Kerala Infrastructure and Technology for Education (KITE) along with a private institution is now engaged in a mission to collect, recycle and refurbish the e-waste produced by schools in different districts of Kerala. The materials include computers, monitors, drives, printers, cameras, ups, projectors, speaker systems, television, generators and various network equipment. 

Recycling

Recycling is an important technique with tremendous potential for innovation used in waste management and comes third in the process of Reduce Reuse Recycle. The practice involves converting waste materials into new, usable products and reducing the filth and making things reusable. Encouraging the use of recyclable products can further take the scope this method by creating a cycle of production and waste management. 

Composting is one of the easiest and natural methods used in the decomposition of biodegradable organic substances in waste management. Aerobic methods like a pit compost, pot composting, ring composting or vermicomposting use microorganisms that require oxygen to decompose organic matter, while microorganisms that do not require oxygen are used in anaerobic methods like biogas, mose pit or pedestal composting.  

Successful waste management has never been an accident. Coordinated activities of both government and civil society required in the healthy implementation of such ambitious projects. All the campaigns above mentioned are asking for more responsible citizens accepting the truth of filth against the conveniences that we opt for many times.

mainheading: Nurturing the youth
author: Dr Ajeesh Ramachandaran
article:
In the past, the adolescent period was wrongly described as a time of severe turmoil and anger. It was a period associated with conflicts, intense depression and mood instability.
