But this is not always the situation. For most adolescents and youth, this is a time of happiness and discovery. This is when they successfully adapt to the various inherent changes that occur physically, mentally and emotionally. It is a point of independent thinking, helping to mould their future careers and personal frontiers. 

 

Youth too, like adults, face distress and have emotional outbursts.  With the support and guidance of parents, teachers and counsellors, such events can be successfully conquered by adolescents without affecting their academic or social life negatively.

 

It is imperative that the importance of social values and good lifestyle is instilled into the youth. Parents, teachers and schools play an important role in enlightening the youth and moulding them accordingly. Adolescents seek inspirations and hence reach out to idols like on-screen personalities, sportsmen, politicians, and even family and close family friends  What's important to note is taking inspiration is acceptable as long as this doesn't hamper with the emergence of the youth 's individual identity, personality and tastes.

 

Adolescence is the time of strong friendships, the emergence of new beliefs and exploring new frontiers. If given the wings and the right guidance, the sky is the limit!

mainheading: How good are we as parents?
author: Vinitha Prabhakar Patil
article:
We always hear about the attitude of today's youngsters. Are they really care less? Are they born stubborn?

 

Any child who comes to this world is innocent and pure. Their attitudes and character are cultivated by the family and the society they live in. The very first time a parent gives in to the unduly cry of a baby is the first lesson learned by the child. Cry, show tantrums and you are going to get things done. From the very beginning, there should be definite and clear 'no’ and 'yes’. While the baby grows, make it a point to explain why it is a 'no’.  Even while growing up, they should be made aware of what is right for them and what is not. And why is something not right for them or not being provided to them immediately on demand. 

 

  We always hear about spending quality time with the kids. It's not only about having dinner together, going out together, sitting together and talking to each other a few minutes every day. That also is necessary. But it would be better if the time is used to create awareness about nature, about their lives as social beings. Take them out to a lawn, walk barefoot. Take them to the beach, pick up beautiful shells with them. Do a bit of gardening with them. Take them to an orphanage at times. Clean the roadside near to your house with them.

 

Help them grow up as socially responsible citizens, also as persons who can enjoy, cherish and love the beautiful nature. We are many times nostalgic about those little things we have seen, done and enjoyed in our childhood. But how many of us, parents have given our children a chance to jump in a shallow stream? How many had the chance to play in the sand? How many know about little joys like collecting Manjadikkuru (Red Lucky Seed) or Kunnikkuru (Jequirity) as we did in our childhood. Such things that might seem to be silly to us now are those which create beautiful memories of childhood. Let them live like children.

 

   The pressures of the present academic system are immense. From the very heavy backpacks to the coaching sessions, kids undergo lots of tensions. Instead of further pressure, let them have an understanding supportive home front. Learn 'about’ your child. Learn about his/her weakness, difficulties they face at their tender age, understand their talents, nurture them. It's not just about making them an engineer or a doctor. It's all about making them successful persons. There are umpteen career options in front of today's kids. Try to understand about various options. The help of career consultants can also be sought. It's not about doing what we wish them to do.

 

It's about selecting what suits them. It's about excelling in what one does. Children, especially those in their teens need emotional support many times. Lacking it at home may make them vulnerable to the influence of anti-social elements who may exploit the situation. As there are no longer joint families, parents should take extra care to give them space and time to open up. That should be done without nagging and irritating the teen who thinks of himself/herself as an adult. Never judge them comparing their acts and >

   

The kids are like diamonds...the care given in shaping and polishing the diamond makes it shine forever. Give the children your love and support. Understand them. Let them grow up to be bright gems that shine brightly.

mainheading: Laws to make children stay protected from the vulture eyes
author: Adv. Jomon Vargheese
article:
Children, irrespective of gender and age are at a risk of sexual abuse at any point in time. It is the greatest of all concerns among parents to make sure that their children stay protected from the vulture eyes of abusers. 

 

The governments from time tried to implement stringent laws to protect the children and women from acts of sexual abuse. The last among them is the POCSO Act  2012(Protection of children from sexual offences act) which is formulated and brought into force from 14/11/2012. The occurrence if notorious Nirbhaya case which happened at Delhi and shook the entire country paved the way for such an immediate enactment. 

 

New offences, special courts, special public prosecutors, mandatory reporting, punishment for false reporting, special procedures, in-camera trials, compensation etc are the salient features of this Act. 

 

The major sections of this Act are sections 3,5,7,9 and 11 which are respectively Penetrative sexual assault, Aggravated penetrative sexual assault, sexual assault, Aggravated sexual assault and sexual harassment.

 

Even though the governments are trying hard to curb any sort of abuse in children, it is the paramount duty of each and every parent to make sure that their child remains safe. It is a disgrace to the entire country, that one out of every 10 women reported some kind of child sexual abuse during childhood, chiefly by known persons.

 

Two million child commercial sex workers between age 5 to 15 lives in India. Proper awareness and stringent laws alone is a practical remedy against these odds. Let's March towards a better and beautiful India.

mainheading: Decoding education: How the curriculums are separated from life itself?
subheading: Proper sex education is yet to be a part of the curriculum. Biology lessons cover the topics about puberty, reproduction etc. Teachers, especially in co-ed schools, just cover the portion fast without many explanations so as to avoid embarrassment.
author: Vinitha Prabhakar Patil
article:
Tini tots who join kindergarten at the age of three or four are pure souls who can be shaped into beautiful personalities by the end of their education. The school education, including the K.G section, consists of fourteen years as per Indian curriculum. Can we say that the students who pass the 12th standard are educated in all aspects according to their age? They learn a lot of subjects in school, earn high marks, yet remain unable to face the real world. The school syllabus in India is really tough and takes entire working hours of the year to be taught. But there are certainly other areas of wisdom to be shared with children according to their age. These include sex education, environmental awareness, general awareness about society etc.

How many of the higher secondary students of present-day know about the functioning of services such as postal service, banking service, electricity or drinking water supply services and the ways in which the payments are made or faults reported? The school syllabus is made in such a way that a lot of academic knowledge is imparted to the child and the child learns them without knowing their real applications in real life. It is high time to rethink whether all these things are to be taught to a child without considering the aptitude and ability of the child.

Proper sex education is yet to be a part of the curriculum. Biology lessons cover the topics about puberty, reproduction etc. Teachers, especially in co-ed schools, just cover the portion fast without many explanations so as to avoid embarrassment. Children often resort to internet and friends and acquire incorrect and dangerous information. Time should be allowed in the curriculum for sessions by doctors, child psychologists and counsellors.  Adolescent children should be made aware of their growth, changing bodies and, psychological aspects related to these changes. They should be made aware of these aspects of the opposite sex too in a teenage-friendly manner.

It is also seen that gender discrimination is embalmed in their minds from a very young age. In small classes itself, they learn that mom is supposed to do this and dad is supposed to that. More about gender discrimination at school level can be discussed in a separate article as there is a lot to write about it. There is no time for kids even to interact properly or play together. In some schools, the lunchtime is just 25 minutes. Students hardly get enough time to have the hot lunch served in the canteen. Let alone playing at school, kids don't get enough time to play at home too. The syllabus needs extra tuitions to learn and acquire good marks. The competitive exams which await them make it necessary to undergo rigorous coaching classes. Coaching for IIT-JEE nowadays starts from class VI.

No extra reading is encouraged in most of the schools. Of course, there are exceptions. Schools which do not encourage extra reading cannot be blamed completely. The teachers barely have time to finish the prescribed portions and revise prior to exams. It is often seen that kids are asked to keep away from gadgets like computers and concentrate only on studies. Instead of banning and evoking unnecessary interest and curiosity, these gadgets can be used as tools for education, moving with the times. There are certain schools in India which have adopted different curriculum, mostly international, where the children of the privileged class only can study. A change from the grass root level only can change the nation. A unified syllabus for the entire country is the need of the hour. Else it will help only in creating more class discrimination.

mainheading: 10 Facts You Must Know About Kerala State School Sports and Games 2017
imgtext: St Joseph's HSS, Pullurampara secured 2nd position in the meet with just 32 participants.
subheading: The four-day sports meet, concluded on Monday, witnessed 2800 students competing in 95 different events at Pala Municipal Stadium. Chief minister, Pinarayi Vijayan, inaugurated the 61st sports meet along with the new synthetic tracks in the stadium.
author: Db Correspondent
article:
1.       The 12th champion title for Ernakulam

Ernakulam district secured the top position and lifted their 12th title of the overall championship in the meet defeating Palakkad, the defending champions, for as much as 73 points. The district had a total of 258 points with 34 gold and 16 silver medals.

2.       Once again, Palakkad had to step down

Palakkad was the crowned champion district in the 60th sports meet held at Malappuram last year defeating Ernakulam for mere 8 points ending its many years of domination. But once again the district had to sit in the second position after the results of this year came out. The district secured 185 points with 22 gold and 4 silver medals.

3.       Kothamanglam Mar Basil made a hat-trick

It was the 5th title of champion school clinched by Mar Basil HSS, Kothamangalam and the 3rd in a row, giving a significant contribution to the victory of Ernakulam district. The school has secured 75 points with 13 gold medals.

4.       Pullurampara St Joseph's HSS emerge as black horses of the event

It was with great surprise that St Joseph's HSS, Pullurampara secured 2nd position in the meet with just 32 participants. The school finished only 12 points behind Mar Basil for champion school title and made crucial contributions to Kozhikode’s point table. The school got 63 points with 7 gold and 9 silver medals, while Kozhikode district secured 109 points with 8 gold and 20 silver medals.

5.       15 new state records and 7 performances crossed national records

It was literally showers of records at Pala, as the state school sports meet witnessed a total of 15 new state records, while seven performances crossed the national records.

6.       7 individual champions were honoured

Senior(Under-19) Girls

1.       Anumol Thampi, Mar Basil HSS, Kothamangalam(3 Gold)

2.       Aparna Roy, St Joseph’s HSS, Pallurampara(3 Gold)

Senior(Under-19) Boys

         Adarsh Gopi, Mar Basil HSS, Kothamangalam(2 Gold, 1 Silver)

Junior(Under-16) Girls

         Ancy Sojan, Nattika Fisheries School, Thrissur(2 Gold, 1 Silver)

Junior(Under-16) Boys

         Abhishek Mathew, Mar Basil HSS, Kothamangalam(3 Gold)

Sub-Junior(Under-14) Girls

         P Abhisha, Mar Basil HSS, Kothamangalam(3 Gold)

Sub-Junior(Under-14) Boys

         Tangjam Aletson Singh, St George HSS, Kothamangalam(3 Gold)

7.       For the first time, criteria were changed from class to age

The 61st school sports meet of Kerala has made history by revamping the criteria of participants from sub-junior, junior and senior to Under-14, Under-16 and Under-19 to avoid older participants playing with the younger ones of the same class. Schools used to fail students deliberately to make them play with younger participants to secure points.

8.      New Synthetic tracks of international standards inaugurated 

Chief minister, Pinarayi Vijayan, inaugurated the new synthetic tracks prepared in the Pala municipal stadium along with the 61st sports meet on 20 October. It is for the first time that the sports meet is happening on synthetic tracks and is praised by experts for keeping international standards.

9.       Held on the banks of Meenachil River

After a long gap of 25 years, state school sports meet had come back to Pala, on the banks of Meenachil river, as the municipal stadium is hosting it for the third time. 2800 participants in three different categories competed in 95 sporting events here. Pala is all set to become the athletic centre of Kerala as sports meets of State CBSE, MG University and Medical University are soon coming to these tracks.

10.   The meet happened under green protocol

The sports meet took place under the strict green protocol by avoiding plastic and disposable materials completely. Plastic bottles and bags were strictly banned from the stadium.

The meet has also arranged yoga for participants with high stress and NADA (National Anti Doping Agency)  to prevent doping among participants.

mainheading: Students of Santa Cruz Higher Secondary School Learn Food Safety Lessons
imgtext: Left to right: Sophiya T P, Headmistress, Santa Cruz HSS, Sanjitha Saleem, CEO, Amalnath N, Director and Arjun J V, Marketing & Promotions Manager, The Daybreak with students.
subheading: In the midst of rising food safety concerns, 'The Daybreak' conducts training sessions at Fort Kochi on safe food practices and personal hygiene.
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
The plot

In an attempt to create awareness regarding food poisoning and risk factors, ‘The DayBreak team’ took featured classes for students at Santa Cruz Higher Secondary School on Friday. Sanjitha Saleem, CEO, The Daybreak enlightened the students with concepts like safe food, bacterial infections, temperature level, acute illness and methods to avoid food poisoning. The session also introduced students to the opportunities if food safety management is chosen as a career option and encouraged them to be stay alert about the food items they eat every day. She is certified by many international agencies to conduct classes on food safety management.

Sophiya TP, Headmistress, Santa Cruz HSS, said "Let us appreciate the team for organising such an informative training class for our children educating them about the safety measures to be adopted while choosing and handling food items. It is very useful for students to know about such practices to avoid illness which may cause due to carelessness and ignorance."

The background 

The cases of food poisoning and acute illness are increasingly reported from different parts of Kerala as revealed by the office of State Food Safety Commissioner. This should be read closely with the increasing number of street food vendors and the new food practices gaining ground. In a press release published on 30 October, 2017 by the commissioner's office reveals that several cases of food poisoning are reported throughout the state, particularly in connection with schools, colleges, hospitals and hostels which initiated various inspection drives in the same. And within a week of inspections in more than 1300 institutions, the commissioner's office received a fine of Rs. 18,7500 and sent improvement notice to 858 establishments while 5 were forced to shut down. 

The essence 

'The Daybreak' took an initiative with a sense of responsibility to hit at the heart of the fire instead of covering it with a lid. The team aims to build awareness among the young minds, who also are the end consumers of tomorrow and arm them with the solutions to this issue. The training session included, what is a safe food?, How food get contaminated?, Who is bacteria and how they mould and destroy our food?, What are the different levels of risks involved with various food items?, How temperature levels affect the food materials?, Who are the most vulnerable groups for food poisoning and how to avoid it?, What are the methods to maintain personal hygiene? and what are the career opportunities available in food safety management?

The curiosity factor

The Daybreak team is determined to reach out to more students and schools to adopt a healthy life>

The review

It is the responsibility of every citizen to look into the matter of food hygiene as it directly affects the health of the whole nation. Let us come together to help ourselves by keeping unsafe food away and maintaining the cleanliness that we all must opt for. Let us know if you wish to conduct food safety management training in your organisation. We are happy to help you.

mainheading: Children's Day: when Nehru gifted a female elephant to Japanese children!
subheading: Every year we celebrate Children's Day or Bal Divas on November 14, the birthday of our first prime minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, to show reverence to his love and affection to kids not only from this country but around the globe. This November, 'The Daybreak' is rediscovering his affection to children through an unusual gift and a letter he wrote that proves his passion for writing letters.
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
Jawaharlal Nehru loved the art of writing letters especially, for children. He used to find time even in his busy schedule to read, write and reply to the letters that he had received every day. The letters he wrote to his daughter, Indira, while still he was in jail during the freedom struggle later became very famous and are popular even today in form of a book, due to the wisdom he expressed in those.

On October 2, 1949, Nehru was having his usual time in reading the letters that he received on that particular day until he was stumbled upon a letter written by some children in Japan. He was extremely happy to read that letter but was amused by their request to have an Indian elephant in a zoo of their country. It was not because they never had an elephant that the children want to see, but because the elephants they so loved were killed during the second world war.

A 15-year old female elephant called Indira -named after his daughter- was immediately sent to Japan as a gift to the children of that country. And so was his love to children that he wrote a letter addressing them and presenting the elephant as a gift from children of his country. For 34 years, Indira lived in Japan and cherished the lives of Japanese children before she died in 1983. 

Just two months after this incident, Nehru had to write another letter, this time to the children of his own country, when K Shankar Pillai, the father of political cartooning in India, started competitions for children, which was addressed through his publication. The letter which brings out Nehru's endless feeling towards children and his extraordinary wisdom about the world we are living in also talks about the Japanese incident and his vision about how children should grow up.

What better to read on Children's Day than the words of Chacha-Ji himself, that even a letter to children, particularly.

Dear Children,

I like being with children and talking to them and, even more, playing with them. For the moment I forget that I am terribly old and it is very long ago since I was a child. But when I sit down to write, I cannot forget my age and the distance that separates you from me. Old people have a habit of delivering sermons and good advice to the young.

I remember that I disliked this very much long ago when I was a boy. So I suppose you do not like it very much either. Grown-ups also have a habit of appearing to be very wise, even though very few of them possess much wisdom. I have not yet quite made up my mind whether I am wise or not. Sometimes listening to others I feel that I must be wise and brilliant and important. Then, looking at myself, I begin to doubt this. In any event, people who are wise do not talk about their wisdom and do not behave as if they were very superior persons...

What then shall I write about? If you were with me, I would love to talk to you about this beautiful world of ours, about flowers, trees, birds, animals, stars, mountains, glaciers and all the other beautiful things that surround us in the world. We have all this beauty all around us and yet we, who are grown-ups, often forget about it and lose ourselves in our arguments or in our quarrels. We sit in our offices and imagine that we are doing very important work.

I hope you will be more sensible and open your eyes and ears to this beauty and life that surrounds you. Can you recognise the flowers by their names and the birds by their singing? How easy it is to make friends with them and with everything in nature if you go to them affectionately and with friendship. You must have read many fairy tales and stories of long ago. But the world itself is the greatest fairy tale and story of adventure that was ever written. Only we must have eyes to see and ears to hear and a mind that opens out to the life and beauty of the world.

Grown-ups have a strange way of putting themselves in compartments and groups. They build barriers... of religion, caste, colour, party, nation, province, language, customs and of rich and poor. Thus they live in prisons of their own making. Fortunately, children do not know much about these barriers, which separate. They play and work with each other and it is only when they grow up that they begin to learn about these barriers from their elders. I hope you will take a long time in growing up...

Some months ago, the children of Japan wrote to me and asked me to send them an elephant. I sent them a beautiful elephant on behalf of the children of India... This noble animal became a symbol of India to them and a link between them and the children of India. I was very happy that this gift of ours gave so much joy to so many children of Japan, and made them think of our country... remember that everywhere there are children like you going to school and work and play, and sometimes quarrelling but always making friends again. You can read about these countries in your books, and when you grow up many of you will visit them. Go there as friends and you will find friends to greet you.

You know we had a very great man amongst us. He was called Mahatma Gandhi. But we used to call him affectionately Bapuji. He was wise, but he did not show off his wisdom. He was simple and childlike in many ways and he loved children... he taught us to face the world cheerfully and with laughter.

Our country is a very big country and there is a great deal to be done by all of us. If each one of us does his or her little bit, then all this mounts up and the country prospers and goes ahead fast.

I have tried to talk to you in this letter as if you were sitting near me, and I have written more than I intended.

Jawaharlal Nehru December 3, 1949

mainheading: 5 Reasons To Celebrate The 61st 'Formation Day' Of Kerala This November
imgtext: Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan receiving the President of India, Ram Nath Kovind in Thiruvananthapuram.
subheading: Kerala Piravi or the formation day marks the birth of the state of Kerala on November 1, 1959, when the three Malayalam speaking princely states of Malabar, Cochin and Travancore were merged together. ‘The Daybreak’ is bringing you some unique developments that took place in November 2017 to celebrate and cherish about the state that crossed its 61st birthday.
author: Db Correspondent
article:
1. President of India hails Keralites as the ambassadors of India.

On his second visit to India after assuming office, Ram Nath Kovind, President of India praised the presence of Keralites in different countries around the world and their role in shaping values for those societies and thus becoming the excellent ambassadors for India. 

"Kerala's fame as educated and enlighted society goes far and wide", he said. 

On 27 October 2017, he was launching the Technocity project, the fourth phase of Technopark in Thiruvananthapuram, where he also hailed the advantages of Kerala in IT, tourism and healthcare sectors. 

2. Kerala and Goa listed as the safest states for women in India

In the first-ever Gender Vulnerability Index (GVI) provided by Plan India and revealed by the women and child development ministry declared Kerala and Goa as the safest among Indian states while Bihar, Jharkhand and UP came last in the list. The Index released on November 2 is prepared against four parameters of education, health, poverty and protection against violence. 

3. Kerala to provide 48-hour free treatment for accident victims

For the first time ever in India, the state is all set to introduce the trauma care scheme which will give free emergency care and treatment for road accident victims for the first 48 hours. The medical expenses for such cases will be paid by the state government through Road Safety fund which can be retrieved from insurance companies. This is to avoid any situation that may deny treatment to victims due to the lack of capacity to pay. The scheme also plans to pool ambulances to a centralized call centre system for the swift evacuation of victims from the site

4. Kerala to give free medical care and insurance to migrant workers. 

In a yet another first in the country, Kerala has launched the scheme, Aavaz, to give the free medical care of Rs.15000 and an insurance cover worth Rs. 2 lakhs for migrant workers in the state. The benefits are expected to initiate from January 1, 2018. 

5. Kerala is offering free sanitary napkins for govt schools 

After a series of pilot test in govt schools, the government of Kerala has launched the scheme, 'She Pad', to make sanitary napkins available free of cost in 300 govt for both teachers and students. The scheme that not only provides free napkins but also gives storage facilities and environment-friendly spaces, is also an attempt to encourage menstrual hygiene.

mainheading: Central government to introduce a ‘national education policy’ by year-end
imgtext: Prakash Javadekar, Union Minister for HRD, Government of India
subheading: Around five million students move around the globe for education.  India is a nation with high outflow of students and there is a need to make India the centre of education as discussed by union ministers, officials and industry leaders in New Delhi.
author: Db correspondent
article:
A new policy on education formulated by the central government of India is expected to be released by December end. The new development is anticipated to liberalise the highly regulated education sector and encourage the private sector participation to acquire global citizenship of India in education. Peculiarities of the policy were discussed by the ministers and high-rank officials in the country at the 13th FICCI Higher Education Summit 2017, a global conference and exhibition on education held in New Delhi on Thursday.

Prakash Javadekar, Union Minister for HRD, in his video message, said that the government had come out with learning outcomes and was providing greater autonomy to the institutes to pursue research and development and innovation. The government has initiated several programs such as ‘Swayam’ to promote online learning and introduced quality benchmarking of institutes to make them competitive globally. 

“The government is in the process of finalizing the new national education policy which will focus on making India’s education system learner-centric instead of teacher-centric. Also, the highly regulated education sector is being liberalized and private sector participation is being encouraged for India to acquire global citizenship in education” said N. Saravana Kumar, Joint Secretary, Ministry of Human Resource Development.

Suresh Prabhu, Union Minister for Commerce & Industry, urged the stakeholders including industry and academic to recommend ideas to promote the business of education globally. With the internet, new business opportunities have emerged and India must take advantage of it.

Sudhanshu Pandey, Joint Secretary, MoCI, said “In the wake of protectionism, knowledge sharing and student exchange programmes become critical and give a new hope for tomorrow. India was among one of the nations with a high outflow of students, the country spends more than $20 billion on students studying abroad and there was a need to make India the centre of education.”

“The student has been at the core of education and shall remain at its epicentre in future as well. The need is to create and facilitate an ecosystem where students can attain excellence in their chosen domains. He added that a bridge of understanding needed to be created between industry and academia so that both can move forward together”, he said.

Nina Vaskunlahti, Ambassador of Finland to India, said that Finland’s education system stands on four pillars of equality, efficiency, quality and internationalism. Finland’s education system is rated among the best in the world and the country would be forthcoming in sharing its knowledge, technology and best practices in the education domain with India.

Sangeeta Godbole, Director General, Services Export Promotion Council (SEPC), said that SEPC,  set up by the Ministry of Commerce & Industry, Government of India, facilitates service exporters of India which includes education sector as well. Going forward, SEPC would bridge the gap between academia and industry while pushing for greater autonomy in the education sector, policy reforms and internationalization of education.

The theme for the summit was ‘Leapfrogging to Education 4.0: Student at the Core’. 67 countries, 1000 delegates of which more than 247 are foreign delegates predominantly from Africa, SAARC, Middle East, CIS, Finland, New Zealand, Malaysia, Australia, USA participated in the summit.

mainheading: ISL 2017-18: Blasters to take ATK while Kochi kicks the Indian football festival
subheading: The new Dutch-born head-coach of Kerala Blasters has already made it clear that his team will be playing an attacking football, which may bring a complete shift from the defensive style endorsed by the team in previous editions.
author: Db Correspondent
article:
With expensive foreign signings, new teams, extended season and the recognition of Asian Football Confederation, the fourth edition of Indian Super League is all set to kickstart the football festival on Friday with a grant inauguration ceremony by Bollywood stars like Salman Khan and Katrina Kaif and a long list of celebrities performing and attending at Jawaharlal Nehru Stadium, Kochi. The defending champions, ATK will take on Kerala Blasters in the inaugural match that will start at 8.00 pm.

Earlier the teams were gone behind big guns and brought many expensive players from foreign shores which include the Bulgarian legend and former Manchester United player Dimitar Berbatov by Kerala Blasters, the ex-Irish international Robbie Keane by ATK and the Venezuelan striker Nicolás Ladislao Fedor Flores (Miku) for Bengaluru FC.

With the addition of hugely popular Bengaluru FC and Tata backed Jamshedpur FC, Indian Super League now have a total of ten teams playing 95 matches for a time span of four months till March. The final match of this fourth edition is scheduled on 17 March at Vivekananda Yuba Bharati Krirangan, Kolkata. The Asian Football Confederation’s recognition to the league prior to this edition is a big boost raising the status of ISL to that must abide by the regulations of AFC and FIFA. According to the new rules, teams had to include at least six Indian players in the playing eleven which will also decrease the number foreign players in a single game. The champions of ISL’s fourth edition will be also playing in the playoff matches of AFC Cup.

The God’s Own Team

Kerala Blasters was one the few teams in ISL to complete the foreign signings early and left no room for confusion which gripped the team during all the previous seasons of the league. A complete revamp in the administration caused swift decisions and popular signings of a new coach and several foreign signings. The team also had a good time in calling for talented Indian players during the transfer market as the coach said they could capture 90% of players they wished for. The greatest of all surprises was the signing of Bulgarian hitman and former Manchester United legend, Dimitar Berbatov.

Rene Meulensteen and the attacking philosophy of game

The new Dutch-born head-coach of Kerala Blasters has already made it clear that his team will be playing an attacking football, which may bring a complete shift from the defensive style endorsed by the team in previous editions. Historically, Blasters had opted for head coaches who had put their interest more into the defence system of the team which helped them to concede very few number of goals compared to other teams. But with Meulensteen taking charge the fans could expect a different game plan altogether. The former aid of Sir Alex Ferguson at Manchester United has raised the hopes of fans too much. With at least four ex-Manchester United men in the team, including defender Wes Brown and goalkeeper Paul Rachubka,  the yellow army may reflect the traits of Red Devils, hopes fans.

mainheading: Nobel Prize 2017: 6 awards, 12 new laureates and everything you need to know
subheading: On December 10, the 12 new Nobel Laureates will be honoured in a grant event at Stockholm, Sweden, when they receive the medals and diplomas from King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden. Meanwhile the Nobel Peace Prize Laureates receive their award from the chairman of Norwegian Nobel Committee in a completely different event held at Oslo, Norway.
author: Db correspondent
article:
Nobel Peace Prize 2017: International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons 

Prestigious of all Nobel Prizes, the award for promoting peace is been awarded to the International Campaign to Abolish Nuclear Weapons (ICAN) for their efforts to ban ever piling up nuclear bombs. ICAN is an alliance of non-governmental organizations in more than one hundred countries supporting commitment to and practising of the United Nations nuclear weapon ban treaty, the landmark global agreement adopted in New York on 7 July 2017. 

As of now, it is estimated that there are at least as much as 15,000 potential nuclear weapons present in the arsenal of world countries. The award committee also appreciated the works of the organization to draw attention to the catastrophic humanitarian consequences of any use of nuclear weapons. Setsuko Thurlow, the 85-year-old survivor of 1945 atomic bombing of Hiroshima will jointly accept the Prize together with ICAN’s executive director, Beatrice Fihn, at the Nobel Peace Prize ceremony in Oslo on 10 December. 

The Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel 2017: Richard H. Thaler

The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences has awarded this year's Nobel Prize for Economic Sciences to Richard H. Thaler for his contributions while incorporating economics and psychology. He integrated psychologically realistic assumptions into analyses of economic decision-making. By exploring the consequences of limited rationality, social preferences, and lack of self-control, he has shown how these human traits systematically affect individual decisions as well as market outcomes.

Thaler is a professor at the University of Chicago and the director of the Center for Decision Research and is the co-director of the Behavioral Economics Project at the National Bureau of Economic Research. Thaler is the co-author of the global bestseller Nudge in which the concepts of behavioural economics are used to tackle many of society’s major problems. In 2015 he published Misbehaving: The Making of Behavioral Economics.

The Nobel Prize in Literature 2017: Kazuo Ishiguro

The Japanese-born British author, Kazuo Ishiguro, was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature, to quote the Swedish Academy,"who, in novels of great emotional force, has uncovered the abyss beneath our illusory sense of connection with the world". As one of the most celebrated English fiction writer in the contemporary world, Kazuo had admitted several times that his Japanese background helped him to look at things in a different perspective. He is the author of Man Booker Prize-winning novel, The Remains of the Day, and his novel, Never Let Me Go, was selected by Time magazine as the best of 2005. 

The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine 2017: Jeffrey C. Hall, Michael Rosbash, Michael W. Young

Acknowledging the glory of their discoveries of molecular mechanisms controlling the circadian rhythm, The Nobel Assembly at Karolinska Institute awarded the Nobel Prize in Medicine jointly to Jeffrey C. Hall, Michael Rosbash and Michael W. Young. 

Do you know that living organisms, including humans, have an internal, biological clock that helps them anticipate and adapt to the regular rhythm of the day or the revolutions of our planet? The new Nobel winning trio was able to peek inside these biological clocks and find out its inner workings. Their discoveries explain how plants, animals and humans adapt their biological rhythm so that it is synchronized with the Earth's revolutions. They have isolated a gene of fruit flies that controls their normal daily biological rhythm and showed that this gene encodes a protein that accumulates in the cell during the night, and is then degraded during the day. Our wellbeing is affected when there is a temporary mismatch between our external environment and this internal biological clock, for example when we travel across several time zones and experience "jet lag". 

Michael Rosbash has been on faculty at Brandeis University in Waltham, USA, since 1974. From 1978, Michael W. Young has been on faculty at the Rockefeller University in New York, while Jeffrey C. Hall is associated with the University of Maine.

The Nobel Prize in Physics 2017: Rainer Weiss, Barry C. Barish, Kip S. Thorne

The Nobel Prize in Physics 2017 was divided, one half awarded to Rainer Weiss, the other half jointly to Barry C. Barish and Kip S. Thorne "for decisive contributions to the LIGO detector and the observation of gravitational waves". Rainer Weiss is an American physicist, known for his contributions to gravitational physics and astrophysics. He is a professor of physics emeritus at MIT and an adjunct professor at LSU. He is best known for inventing the laser interferometric technique which is the basic operation of LIGO. He was Chair of the COBE Science Working Group. 

Barry Barish is an American experimental physicist. He is a Linde Professor of Physics, emeritus at California Institute of Technology and leading expert on gravitational waves. Kip Stephen Thorne is an American theoretical physicist known for his contributions to gravitational physics and astrophysics. A longtime friend and colleague of Stephen Hawking and Carl Sagan, he was the Feynman Professor of Theoretical Physics at the California Institute of Technology(Caltech) until 2009 and is one of the world's leading experts on the astrophysical implications of Einstein's general theory of relativity. He continues to do scientific research and scientific consulting, most notably for the Christopher Nolan film Interstellar.

The Nobel Prize in Chemistry 2017: Jacques Dubochet, Joachim Frank, Richard Henderson

The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences has decided to award the Nobel Prize in Chemistry 2017 to Jacques Dubochet, Joachim Frank and Richard Henderson, quoting the academy "for developing cryo-electron microscopy for the high-resolution structure determination of biomolecules in solution". The development of cryo-electron microscopy may help both in simplifying and improving the images of biomolecules. This method has definitely moved biochemistry into a new era. Electron microscopes were long believed to only be suitable for imaging dead matter because the powerful electron beam destroys the biological material. But in 1990, Richard Henderson succeeded in using an electron microscope to generate a three-dimensional image of a protein at atomic resolution. 

Jacques Dubochet is an honorary professor of Biophysics at the University of Lausanne, Switzerland. Joachim Frank, German-born professor of Biochemistry and Molecular Biophysics and of Biological Sciences at Columbia University, New York, USA. Richard Henderson is a programme Leader at MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology, Cambridge, UK.

The new Nobel Laureates will be honoured in a grant event at Stockholm, Sweden, when they receive the medals and diplomas from King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden on December 10, while the Nobel Peace Prize Laureates receive their award from the chairman of Norwegian Nobel Committee in a completely different event held at Oslo, Norway on the same day.

mainheading: MR Vaccine: Kerala Immunises 85% of its children against Measles and Rubella
subheading: MR Vaccination Campaign is a part of Universal Immunisation Programme under the Union Ministry of Health and Family Welfare launched on February 5, 2017, to eradicate these deadly diseases by vaccinating approximately 41 crore children in the country in a phased manner, thus becoming the largest vaccination campaign attempted anywhere.
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
In a mission to eradicate the two deadly diseases measles and rubella, from the country, the state of Kerala has vaccinated 85% of its children, i.e. 60 lakh kids between 9 months and 15 years, and has extended the final date till November 25 with an intention to achieve 100% immunisation coverage. As per the data till November 18, as much as 59,66,309 children in the state received MR vaccination in the intensive campaign that started on October 3. The three districts of Pathanamthitta, Kollam and Alappuzha had successfully completed the campaign with more than 95% of children immunised.   

Measles is a life-threatening disease and is one of the major cause of death in children. It is highly contagious and spreads through coughing and sneezing of an infected person. Measles can make a child vulnerable to complications such as pneumonia, diarrhoea and brain infection. Globally, in 2015, measles killed an estimated 1, 34,200 children—mostly under-5 years. In India, it killed an estimated 49,200 children.   

Rubella is generally a mild infection but has serious consequences if infection occurs in pregnant women, causing congenital rubella syndrome (CRS), which is a cause of public health concern. CRS is characterized by congenital anomalies in the foetus and new-borns affecting the eyes (glaucoma, cataract), ears (hearing loss), brain (microcephaly, mental retardation) and heart defects, causing a huge socioeconomic burden on the families and society.   

The state has trained caregivers, school teachers, Anganwadi workers and frontline health workers for this campaign, while also had parallel counselling and awareness programs to attract parents and the general public. The original plan was to achieve 100% coverage by November 3 through an intensive campaign. But the vaccination programme was destined to face several challenges and had to postpone the final date until 18 November, which now again got extended till November 25. The government has asked schools, health centres and hospitals to continue vaccination even after the deadline to achieve total vaccination and complete eradication of these diseases.   

MR Vaccination Campaign is a part of Universal Immunisation Programme under the Union Ministry of Health and Family Welfare launched on February 5, 2017, to eradicate these deadly diseases by vaccinating approximately 41 crore children in the country in a phased manner, thus becoming the largest vaccination campaign attempted anywhere. During the first phase, the states Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, Goa, Pondicherry and Lakshadweep had already vaccinated around 3.32 crore children until March 31, 2017. The second phase that started in early October is anticipated to cover 3.4 crore children spread across eight states including Kerala. After completion of this campaign, MR vaccine will replace the Measles vaccine and will a part of routine Immunisation soon.   

Polio, Measles and Rubella are the only three diseases transmitted by humans and only found in human beings. So, it is viable to eradicate the disease if proper vaccination is received in right time.

mainheading: Uber and NASA to Fly 'Air Taxis' by 2020: 5 Things You Should Know
subheading: 'Uber Elevate' is an ambitious program designed by the biggest taxi service provider on the planet to develop a future air transport system using 'flying cars' to move commuters between sky ports.
author: Db correspondent
article:
1. Uber is teaming up with NASA

To develop a brand-new air traffic management system, Uber has signed a Space Act Agreement with National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) of United States. NASA is into building a basic framework and is expected to provide logical support to manage the low flying, autonomous aerial taxi service. 

2. Aircrafts are designed to move vertically 

'Electric Vertical Take-Off and Landing Vehicles' (EVTOLs) are specially designed aircrafts visualised by Uber with the ability to take-off and land vertically, which may move from rooftop to rooftop of tall buildings. As the technology for such infrastructure doesn't exist yet, the sceptics say, the company will transcend the current operating methods, if the project succeeds. 

3. The aircrafts will soar in sky with 322 Kmph  speed 

 As the company claims, EVTOLs can fly at a maximum speed of 322 Kmph and finish off a trip in 15 minutes, that may otherwise take an hour and a half to complete. The company is taking advantage of the space above urban centres to reduce congestion on the ground and to make cities more open and accessible for everyone.  

4. The three cities lucky to have first 'flying cars' 

Dallas – Fort Worth, Dubai and Los Angeles are the three global cities fortunate enough to have the 'flying cars' on their skies as announced by Uber. The aerial taxi is anticipated to pilot the services by 2020 in these cities. The urban centres are selected according to the traffic congestion and time management pressures they face today.  

5. Full-fledged operations before 'Los Angeles Olympics' 2028 

Ten years from now, Uber envisions of getting air taxi operational before the Los Angeles Olympics of 2028.  The forthcoming multi-sport event, the summer Olympics of 2028 will be held in the city of Los Angeles, California, the USA between July 21 and August 6, 2028. As one of the most traffic affected the city on the planet, EVTOLs are looking forward to easing the vehicle mobility and speed travelling.  

Jeff Holden, Chief Product Officer, Uber says "So far, we have been focusing on ground-based transportation and for us, the natural next step is flying. Flying can really replace driving as in many cases it is taking people's precious time and it can be done in a way that is ultimately less expensive than car ownership as well as friendly to environment and community. But the big win is time-saving. Trips that can take hours on the ground can be reduced to minutes in the air. Giving time back to people is something we are very passionate about in Uber. That's more time with family, more time for growing our economy and lower stress for everyone."

mainheading: I LIKE SPRING,  BECAUSE YOU MADE IT SO
author: Aswathy Achu
article:
I like spring, because you made it so.

you gave the name, you made the showers.

you put the dew on my eyelids.

and from you the season came.

The rhythm of the season reached my ears,

with its blooming buds of love.

lily, Jasmine and the queenliest rose

ran into the queue, made the bouquet.

The garland you made with passion

made me a bride, 

within the braids, it seems like an apparition on the sky

telling my future, the next spring.

who made thine eyes? vaster than the sea, brighter than a pearl, reflects mine.

it makes me fall into it and die

towards the empire of eternity.

mainheading: ISRO to double its launching frequency to 20 satellites in a year: Chairman
subheading: India is poised to become a front-runner among the World’s space program by fostering partnerships in the friendly South Asian countries along with Russia and Japan which further translates towards the creation of a huge pool of high-value high-wage jobs in various advanced technology sectors.
author: Db correspondent
article:
In a two-day International Seminar on “Indian Space Programme" held at New Delhi on November 20, 2017, ISRO Chairman, AS Kiran Kumar, announced that the agency will soon be doubling its launching frequency from 9-10 to about 20 in a year. The event organised by FICCI also saw the launch of a Space Compendium, which showcases the products and services available in Space and Satellite industry in India for greater cooperation in B2B and B2G space.

AS Kiran Kumar, Chairman, ISRO said “World of space is rapidly changing with technological advancements and disruptive innovation. Key to success is to significantly reduce the cost of access to space in what will prove to be an immense opportunity for the Indian and global industry”. He also mentioned that ‘space industry in India is significantly short of capacity for our intended goals’. He emphasised the fact that with increasing volumes that are on offer by ISRO and other Space Agencies, it is an ideal opportunity for the industry to be part of the global supply chain.

The prognosis for Indian industry looks particularly bright with the immense benefits emanating from a developed space ecosystem which directly augment such widely impacting sectors such as Telecommunications, GIS, Agriculture, Meteorology, Mining and Natural resource conservation. This further translates towards creation of a huge pool of high value-high wage jobs in various advanced technology sectors

Ratan Shrivastava, Honorary Advisor, FICCI Space Division said “ISRO is the true flag bearer of the Make In India statement and almost 80% of the work related to Launch vehicles is being done by the Industry, both in public and private sector, which allows ISRO to focus on the core areas of vehicle engineering, vehicle integration, mission systems and Quality Assurance.”

HS Shankar, Chairman, FICCI Space Committee, mentioned that ISRO and the Industry share a Guru-Disciple relationship, where ISRO has played the role of a guide to Indian space industry by hand-holding and mentoring the upcoming and nascent private space and satellite industry. He lauded ISRO for involving more than over a hundred MSMEs as active participants in their programmes. He also stated that “For cooperation in space, Sky is not the limit.”

mainheading: In the midst of migratory season, Kochi to go for a bird spotting race this Sunday
imgtext: Yellow Footed Green Pigeon. Pic by Vishnupriyan Kartha, Secretary, Cochin Natural History Society.
subheading: The contestants will meet to share experiences of the day, cross-check and collate the sightings, determine which of the commonest birds missed, which of the rarest ones and who were the lucky to spot etc., with fellow travellers. The event is open to the public including students and is without any registration fees.
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
As the winter already started and birds are having their migratory season, Cochin Natural History Society (CNHS) is organising the Kerala Bird Race 2017 at Kochi and outskirts on November 26 in its eleventh iteration. The Bird Race -though it has a competitive tone in it- is not a race yet encourages to push the limits to watch, listen, experience and record as many as birds during the course of a day. The participants can record their bird sightings on eBird Website using the eBird mobile App. After a hectic day of birding in the surrounding areas of Kochi city and outskirts- up to 50 km radius- the contestants will meet at a suitable place to share experiences of the day, cross-check and collate the sightings, determine which of the commonest birds missed; which of the rarest ones and who were the lucky to spot etc., with fellow travellers. 

Birds always fascinate and intrigue us with their colours, shapes, songs, calls and their jizz which can move the hearts of even driest of the humans. We are in the midst of the migratory birding season and now we can see many winged beauties in monochromes, duo tones and multicolour- vibgyor, both occurring throughout the year in our state and those who come to visit and enthrall us with the myriad hues and huge repertoire of songs from other parts of the globe during this time of the year. The Bird Race with its fun element is the perfect reason and time to observe and enjoy the beauties in the company of our friends, family or expert birders. 

Training Session 

The event will also have a briefing session for new birdwatchers and experienced ones to interact with each other on the previous day of the race- at Mangalavanam Bird Sanctuary at 5 pm on Saturday, November 25.

mainheading: She
author: Ashwathy Achu
article:
Some day earth will cease its motion.

Scattered planets will be there.

Who cares the sun?

Let him burn,
Burn into ashes
Before he attack the stars
Whom he feels inferior to him.

Who called the sun 'he'?
Why cant it be a 'she'?
With gorgeous wings of fire
In her bright burning skin
Moves golden flakes of beauty
Makes her prettier than ever.

She is 'sun'

Like a forbidden fruit above there
As precious as a piece of ruby
Wipes away the darkness in minds.

She moves from east to west
Hides herself beneath the horizon
So Ends a day.
Her brightness might cheat her
But her boldness won't .

Let her not hide.
Let her rise and shine.
_____
