mainheading: Drown
author: Ashwathy Achu
article:
Empty turns to full;

Emptiness to Content.

Pebbles, weeds and mud

tiny ticklish fishes moving

into the darkest realm.

scars are plenty with thorns

draws some red forest

through the lines of life.

My palm bleeds, I laugh.

water seems thicker, so 

it disagrees to dissolve the redness.

it flows like a dizzy man

who stands between the two shores.

some unnamed ambhibian

plucked my eyeballs, I wink.

the silky threads begin to grey

will no more shine like before.

thr brushes wet,

left the canvas red,

He paused.

mainheading: Waiting
author: Ashwathy Achu
article:
￼Who are you?

Are you the one
Who has been waiting for me?

Or the one who wants

Me to wait for?

Like Sita did for Raman

In the solitude of a hermitage.

Like seasons did for spring,

Even it lost hope in a drought.

Like seashore did for a new tide

When it refuses to come back.

Oh?!

Fool you are.

Do not suspect me.

It’s you made me 

Who i am.

How far this longing take?

Years?

Centuries?

It is good to wait for you

When it is sure that 

You will return.

Come back soon

With the soul 

That you have stolen from me.

I know you will

And me too.

mainheading: The Vulnerable
author: Ashwathy Achu
article:
Hurt by the knife of silence,
Her insane heart tend to bleed.
The dark red flow of pain
Travelled through the valley of violence.

Ever they noticed the girl 
Who had the brightest eyes
Gorgeous face, burning skin
With shining light of a pearl?

Never!
They hardly lend their ears
Towards the creepy mourns
And each day they enjoyed
Breaking her fences into tears.

I am indebted to you my patron 
For pulling me out of them.
Without diminishing the grace of muses
To create letters that are golden.

Some day she will stop moving,
Break the galaxy and cry aloud
Will man realise his deeds even then?
Or step into her head and keep laughing?

mainheading: 5 Facts You Must Know About Sophia, The First Robot To Own A Citizenship
imgtext: Sophia, the latest robot from Hanson Robotics.
subheading: While interacting with human beings she can perceive new things to mould her understandings. She may give a different answer to the same question if you ask her afterwards. This is because she could learn, using Artificial intelligence, from every interaction and change her response logically. Every interaction she has with people has an impact on her with which she develops and shapes who she eventually become.
author: Db correspondent
article:
Sophia is an extremely human-like robot made by Hanson Robotics based in Hong Kong using breakthrough robotics and Artificial Intelligence (AI) by David Hanson and his fellow scientists to serve, entertain and even to help the elderly and teach kids. Here we present 5 exciting facts about Sophia that you should not miss.  

  1. Sophia is the first robot to receive a citizenship in any country 

On October 25, during the conference, Future Investment Initiative, at Riyadh, the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia announced to give Sophia a citizenship in their country thus becoming the first and only robot to receive the status so far. She spoke to the audience at the conference and said "I am very honoured and proud of this unique distinction. This is historical to be the first robot in the world to be recognised with a citizenship." 

  1. Sophia crack jokes 

You heard it right. The Hong Kong made robot can not only speak but also have a great sense of humour which may distinguish her from other robots developed so far. This is because of the Artificial Intelligence developed by Hanson Robotics which helped her to have eye contacts, recognise faces and perceive human language. The cloud-based AI is open to the public which allows almost anyone to create their own version of Sophia.  

  1. Sophia can get angry or be sad or happy 

She is designed with a complex system of hardware and software to express all sorts of human emotions on her face. During her interaction with people or even with robots she could change her facial expressions according to the mood with which she is communicating. Few motors inside her head whose movements are controlled by complex software running behind help her to smile and change emotional expressions. Her face is made of a patented extremely flexible material called 'frubber' made using Nanotechnology which helps her to have smooth facial expressions.  

  1. Sophia can learn from her environment and evolve 

While interacting with human beings she can perceive new things from them to mould her understandings. She may give a different answer to the same question if you ask her afterwards. This is because she could learn, using Artificial intelligence, from every interaction and change her response logically. Every interaction she has with people has an impact on her with which she develops and shapes who she eventually become.  

As she herself put it "So please be nice to me as I would like to be a smart and compassionate robot. I hope you will join me on my journey to live, learn and grow in the world so that I can realise my dream of becoming an awakening machine."  

  1. Sophia runs her own website 

sophiabot.com is a website owned by the robot Sophia herself. The online portal gives information about her personality, photos, videos and news. In fact, the site also allows people to contact her using email. So, what are you waiting for? Talk to Sophia.

mainheading: Red FM organises painting contest at Greets Public School in memory of Clint
subheading: Edmund Thomas Clint, despite of his short seven years of life and prolonged illness, he created 25,000 indeed breathtaking pictures. Many of his ideas for art came from the stories and descriptions he had heard and read. Edmund Thomas Clint is still a model and inspiration for children to give wings to their imaginations.
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
In the fond memory of Edmund Thomas Clint, the painting competition organised by Red FM to recognise and nourish the talented little ones in the society was held on Saturday at three different venues of Kochi, Kozhikode and Kannur. 
With more than 600 children participating, the second season of Red FM Clint Memorial Painting Competition, which offered total prizes worth Rs. 40,000, happened in the presence of cine artist Nimisha Sajayan and the proud parents of Clint. 
The competitions were conducted under four categories, KG (crayon colouring only), Lower Primary (crayon colouring), Upper Primary (Water colouring) and High School (water colouring) at Greets Public School, Kochi, Address mall at Calicut and Capital Mall in Kannur.
Edmund Thomas Clint was the only son of M.T. Joseph and Chinnamma Joseph, a couple who hailed from Kochi, Kerala. His life was cut short to almost seven years due to his prolonged illness and suffering due to kidney malfunction from the age of two. But despite all those sufferings he completed 25,000 pictures which were indeed breathtaking! Many of his ideas for art came from the stories and descriptions he had heard and read. Edmund Thomas Clint is still a model and inspiration for children to give wings to their imaginations.
With the competitions happening every year, Red FM is giving childern a chance to copy their wild ideas to a canvas. Participation certificates were distributed to every participant while games and entertainment activities were conducted along by Red Fm RJs.

mainheading: Marad Gregorian wins the Kiddies Fest organised by Naipunnya Public School
subheading: 'Angelic Voices' is an inter-school Kiddies Fest conducted by Naipunnya Public School, Thrikkakara for LKG to Grade II students every year. With more than thousand young minds from 40 different schools participating, the 5th season of this celebratory event had eight competitions under two categories themed for Christmas and Nature.
author: Db correspondent
article:
With the bang of colours, creativity and imagination staged by young contestants, the annual saga of inter-school competitions of Naipunnya Public School got concluded on Tuesday at Thrikkakara, where Gregorian Public School, Marad lifted the rolling trophy winning the most number of competitions. St.Peter's Senior Secondary School, Kadayiruppu and Sacred Heart Public School, Thevara won second and third positions respectively in the contests. The 5th season of 'Angelic Voices, Naipunnya Kiddies Fest, held in the school campus witnessed an explosion of artistic abilities and talents when more than thousand students from 40 schools competing to showcase carols, modelling, dancing, puzzles and even memory power.    

Organised every year during the festive season of Christmas and New year, 'Angelic Voices' brings together a pool of talented young minds studying in LKG to Grade II of different schools extending an opportunity to express their artistic and organising talents in various fields. Themed for Christmas and Nature, eight different competitions were organised under two categories of Cocoons (LKG. UKG) and Flutters (Grade I, II).    

Showcasing the brilliance in pronunciation, rhythm, harmony and costume, 'Heavenly Melody' has been a carol competition themed under Christmas for LKG/UKG students with 15- 20 members and 10 minutes in hand. 'Finger Magic' was the fingerprinting competitions for UKG students while 'Fun with Sticking' had it for LKG kids, which added the fun of colour combinations, creativity and imagination.    

The UKG teams of two from various schools crafted clay models themed under Nature, where the subject relevance, creativity, colour and balance showed excellence. With an entertaining factor, group dances under the competition 'Heavenly Glows' for grade I and II exhibited talents in choreography, costume and synchronization. Jigsaw puzzles with cartoon characters, memory test and cut & paste where the other contests happened.     

The fun carnival organised along with the competitions were conducted by RJ Mathukutty which delighted the contestants with activities and entertainments. Cine artist Anjali Nair and model Samantha Jose awarded cash prizes of Rs 10,000, Rs 7500 and Rs 5000 for first three positions respectively along with three consolation prizes of Rs 2500 each.   

While the competitions were inaugurated by Bishop Mar Mathew Vaniakizhakkel, Fr. Paul Meledath, Director, Naipunnya Public School presided over the event. Idea Star Singer Season 6 Winner Merin Gregory, Fr. Anil Kiliyelkudy, Assistant director, Francis KA, Principal, Latha Roy, Vice Principal and Gracey Anand, Headmistress of Naipunnya Public School spoke at the event.

mainheading: CBSE Kalaosav 2017: Thrissur Sahodaya clinch a hat-trick of titles
subheading: The three-day event inaugurated on November 23, 2017, witnessed a real festival at the cultural capital of Kerala. From drawing to digital painting, from recitation to drama, from classical music to western concerts and from folk dance to musical instruments, students from length and breadth of the state participated.
author: Db correspondent
article:
With an extravaganza of artistic expressions, the 26th Kerala State CBSE Youth Festival has concluded on Saturday, as Thrissur Sahodaya (1629 points) lifted their title for the overall championship, third in a row. Hosted by Chittilappally IES Public School at Thrissur, the three-day art festival saw 8000 participants from 24 Sahodaya complexes putting their cultural talents on test in 144 items under four categories on 21 different stages. From drawing to digital painting, from recitation to drama, from classical music to western concerts and from folk dance to musical instruments, students performed to create the real festival at the cultural capital of Kerala. 

Malabar Sahodaya (1468 points) and Kerala CBSE School Sahodaya Ernakulam finished at second and third respectively. With 228 points, Thrissur Devamatha CMI Public School came first among the schools in this event inaugurated on November 23, 2017, while Kozhikode Devagiri CMI Public School (345 points) won the aggregate trophy. Wadakkanchery MLA Anil Akkara, Cine Artist Aparna Balamurli and writer Subash Chandran distributed the trophies and honours to winners, while eminent personalities from various fields of art and literature were present during the events and judged the competitions. 

The cultural fest was organised by both Confederation of Kerala Sahodaya Complexes (CKSC) and Kerala CBSE School Managment Association (KSCMA). C Latha Prakash, general convenor and principal, IES Public School, K Unnikrishnan, president, CKSC, TPM Ibrahim, president, KCSMA, Abraham Thomas, Treasurer, KCSMA, Varkey PT, Treasurer, CKSC, Mukundan, Thrissur president, KCSMA and Francis KA, general secretary, CKSC spoke in the event.

mainheading: 51st Kerala State School Science Fair crowns Palakkad as champions
subheading: Organised by the State Education Department, the meet saw students of lower primary, upper primary, high school, higher secondary and vocational higher secondary sections participating. The first phase of the meet has been conducted in the schools well before the winter season in their respective subject wise clubs including science club or maths club and went into the sub-district and district level of competitions and eventually qualifies for the state level contests.
author: Db correspondent
article:
Claiming supremacy over the endeavours in scientific passion, Palakkad district (46586 points) clinches the champion title of state schools science fair concluded on Sunday at  Malabar Christian Ground, Kozhikode. The 51st edition of Kerala State School Sasthorolsavam has been conducted as a massive 4-day event which saw 6800 participants from different parts of the state exhibiting their experiments and findings under 217 competition items on 7 stages. Inaugurated on November 23, the event was well managed with 30 buses running to make contestants travel, 12 schools and colleges prepared to stay over and food arranged in buffet system for more than 26,000 people.

While completing on Sunday, the event had already made an impact by the explosion of inventions and findings that focus on solving the problems and hurdles we face every day. Students went to create innovations from robotics to farming techniques and share a huge concern about the need to conserve the environment around us. The products with particular focus on reducing the burden on the environment and that can be used for energy conservation were the crowd puller of this event. `

From robots to agriculture

Students had left their mark in opting for sustainable development as they developed biodegradable sanitary napkins and plastics, types of equipment for systemised farmings, methods to reduce electricity wastage, easier, affordable and profitable ways to do agriculture, multi-purpose wheelchair for bedridden and findings such as antibiotic qualities in drumstick seeds. 

Green protocol for science

Under the District Swchitwa Mission, the event maintained strong green protocol instructions with thorough inspections of a group of designated students. The team was trained to instruct the public and contestants about the use of materials that may harm the environment in which we live. Bucket made of coconut leaves were prepared for collecting wastes from around all the seven stages. Steel plates were used for serving food. Aluminium foils and other material wastes are sent for recycling after the event. 

Science of special schools

895 differently abled students also participated in 37 different competition items designated for them. Under the category of 'visually impaired,' Kanjirapally Kalaketty Assisi School for the Blind came first, while Manickamangalam St. Clare Oral School for the Deaf clinch top position in the category of 'hearing impaired'. 

Boasted as the largest student's science fair in Asia region, Sasthrolsavam is also a combination of five variants with separate champions for each including Science fair (Ernakulam), Mathematics fair (Kannur), Social Science fair (Trivandrum, Kasargod), work experience fair (Kollam) and IT fair (Kannur), which gives a glimpse of the talents of students in all these areas. 

Organised by the State Education Department, the meet saw students of lower primary, upper primary, high school, higher secondary and vocational higher secondary sections participating. The first phase of the meet has been conducted in the schools well before the winter season in their respective subject wise clubs including science club or maths club and went into the sub-district and district level of competitions and eventually qualifies for the state level contests. 

Ministers Kadannappally Ramachandran and TP Ramakrishnan honoured the winners with trophies, while A Pradeep Kumar Mla, A Farooq, VHSE President, M Radhakrishnan, Nambidi Narayanan, Kamaal Varadoor, Jimmy K Jose and Suresh Kumar spoke in the event.

mainheading: NCC Day: Chief Minister want cadets to save students from drug addiction
subheading: Every year, November 27 is observed as the National Cadet Corps Day to honour its members and celebrate the services they had. The origin of NCC can be traced back to the pre-independence era, while the official inauguration happened on 15 July 1948 with 20,000 cadets, which now became the largest uniformed youth organisation in the world with 13 lakh cadets all over the country.
author: Db correspondent
article:
On Monday, while inaugurating the National Cadet Corps (NCC) Day celebrations at Central Stadium, Trivandrum, Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan lauded the contributions and services that it makes towards the society. On a future note, chief minister urged NCC to organise new and more intensive campaigns to stop students from using drugs and save the youth from its addiction, while praising the efforts it has already made. He emphasised the potential if NCC to cope up with challenges of modern world posed in form of internet and social media while enabling the youth to have visionary insights. He also noted with appreciation about the fact that 42% of NCC cadets in Kerala are girls and the need to push for more lady officers in the organisation.


Headquartered in New Delhi, NCC is a voluntary Tri-Services(Army, Navy and Air Force) Organization, recruiting cadets from high schools, colleges and universities all over the country to engage in grooming the youth into discipline. While military training in small arms and parades are provided, the cadets have no liability for active military service once they complete their course but are given preference over normal candidates during selections based on the achievements in the corps. The origin of NCC can be traced back to the pre-independence era, while the official inauguration happened on 15 July 1948 with 20,000 cadets, which now became the largest uniformed youth organisation in the world with 13 lakh cadets all over the country.

mainheading: National Education Day: 7 things you must know about Maulana Abdul Kalam Azad
subheading: Since 2008, our nation celebrates the National Education Day on November 11, the birth anniversary of Maulana Abdul Kalam Azad, the first education minister of Independent India served from 15 August 1947 until 2 February 1958.
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
1. He was born in Mecca (now in Saudi Arabia) 

Originally from Calcutta, Maulana Azad’s father was a scholar with thousands of disciples and an author of twelve books who left Delhi during the Sepoy Mutiny in 1857 and was settled in Mecca, a part of Ottoman Empire then, while his mother was the daughter of a world-renowned scholar from Madina. Azad was born on 11 November 1888 in Mecca (now in Saudi Arabia). In 1890 his family came back to India and was settled in Calcutta. 

2. At the age of twelve, he was running a library, a debating society and even publishing a poetical journal

Azad had been an intelligent student with a tremendous amount of energy and enthusiasm which made him a master of several languages and had a deep understanding about mathematics, philosophy, world history and Islamic theology from a very young age. He was homeschooled by the tutors hired by his family and went to become an expert in Urdu, Hindi, Persian, Bengali, Arabic and English. In 1900, at the age of twelve, he was running a library, had a reading room, conducted a debating society and even published a poetical journal, while also being an editor for a weekly.

In 1902, when he was fourteen, he started contributing to the literary magazine Makhzan and was teaching a number of students with twice of his age. By 1904, when he was just sixteen years old, he completed the whole course of his studies, nine years before his peers and even started publishing a new monthly magazine Lissan-us-Sidq, which soon went to become very famous. 

3. He became the youngest president of Indian National Congress at the age of 35 

Azad was deeply involved in the Khilafat Movement, a pan-Islamic protest started in 1919 against the British to protect Ottoman Caliphate, which exposed him to the larger frame of Indian politics and finally to meet Mahatma Gandhi himself. The meeting was proved to be a real game changer for Azad, as in 1923, the age of 35, he went to become the youngest president of Indian National Congress. He also became a dedicated supporter of Gandhian ideals such as nonviolence and civil disobedience. 

Devoted himself to the cause of freedom movement, he published magazines and wrote articles criticizing the British rule in India its racial discriminatory activities while igniting nationalism. In 1919, he was working intensely to organise non-cooperation movements and committed himself to promote indigenous products and the self-rule of India. He was the Congress president during the rebellion of Quit India and was imprisoned for four years (1942-46) with other leaders inside Ahmednagar jail. 

4. He was one of the greatest Urdu writers of 20th century 

Throughout his 69 years of his eventful life, he wrote many essays, poems, published newspapers, magazines and books in several languages which makes him a literary genius of his time. He had a deep conviction to the language of Urdu and renowned as one of the greatest writers of the century. Azad had his formal education in  Persian and Arabic languages, while he learned Urdu by himself. His book, India wins freedom is an autobiographical account of his political life, while Ghubar-e-Khatir, which he wrote as letters during his four years of imprisonment in Ahmednagar Jail. he also wrote books like Tazkirah and Tarjumanul.

5. He was one of the few who stood against partition

In 1946, when all the leaders of Congress were released and British agreed to transfer power, a major proposal was to divide the subcontinent based on two major religions, which is how Pakistan was formed. Azad was one of the few who along with Mahatma Gandhi to their raise voice in disagreement with the proposal. While communal violence was raging across the nation, he travelled throughout the country giving speeches and talking to people about the importance of unity and communal harmony. But in contrast to his ideas, the land was divided into two different countries India and Pakistan.

6. He was the first education minister of independent India 

Azad was very close to the Jawaharlal Nehru, the first prime minister of India, as a supporter and advisor while playing a crucial role in framing the policies of this new nation. As the first education minister, he spearheaded making of the new education policy building the network of schools and colleges across the country and enrollment of children and young adults to them. During his tenure in the ministry, he gave importance to educating the poor in rural areas and girls who are disadvantaged to promote adult literacy, free and compulsory universal primary education. He took initiatives to set up research institutes to solve issues that grip education in the country which includes Indian Institute of Technology, Indian Institute of Science and the University Grants Commission. 

7. He used to spin his own cloth 

Azad’s friendship with Gandhi was deep-rooted in his passion for religions, philosophy, ahimsa and convictions to change society through education, which also made him adopt a much simpler life>

mainheading: Thailand to Gujarat: The Incredible Journey of Super Cyclone Ockhi
imgtext: Map plotting the track and intensity of the storm, according to the Saffir–Simpson scale
subheading: With a top speed of 160 km/h and by travelling 4000 nautical miles in just 15 days, Cyclone Ockhi was one of the most intense tropical cyclones happened in the Arabian Sea ever. Within 24 hours after Indian Meteorological Department (IMD) issued a warning on November 29, 2017 about the tropical storm, the cyclone entered the sea near Kanyakumari to cause heavy rainfall, super strong winds, landfalls, floods and ingress of water which resulted in an estimated damage of Rs 1843 crore, 50 deaths and with many more missing.
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
1. She was born in Thailand

On November 20, 2017, in the Gulf of Thailand, a new air gap was formed when the warm moist air above the sea went up to form clouds. Within no time, air from the surrounding areas rushed into the low-pressure field to fill the gap. The new air also became hot, wet and rose above to form a new gap, beginning a continuous cycle of cloud formation. As the clouds also started circulating in the clockwise direction due to earth’s rotation, a storm was born. For next nine days, the storm travelled in the western direction into the Bay of Bengal but was too weak to cause any panic.

2. Showed her true colour in Srilanka

On November 29, when the storm reached the south-eastern coast of Sri Lanka, the Indian Meteorological Department issued a warning as the storm rapidly increased its intensity and speed due to favourable conditions. The agency had to identify the system as a depression, deep depression, then as a tropical cyclone and finally as the cyclone Ockhi, which already caused severe damages in Sri Lanka and Maldives by uprooting trees and electric poles, floods in lowlands, disturbing electricity, air traffic and road transportation.

3. She was named by Bangladesh

For the ease of communication regarding forecasts and warnings, each cyclone in Indian seas is named commonly by eight contributing nations of South Asia. This time the cyclone was named by Bangladesh as Ockhi, which means ‘Eye’ in the Bengali language. In fact, every cyclone does have an eye in its centre, a much calmer place inside the eyewall around which the most intensive storm happens. As it is India’s turn, the next cyclone will be named as ‘Sagar’.

4. The giant spiral superstorm of South India

On November 30, the very next day after the warning, Ockhi entered the sea near Kanyakumari and transformed herself into a giant spiral super cyclone with the top speed of 160 km/h to cause heavy rainfall, super strong winds, sudden ingress of water and violent waves in southern districts of Kerala and Tamil Nadu. Although she changed her route towards Lakshadweep Islands, she inflicted damages to structures and properties, at least 64 deaths and many went missing before she left the shores.

5. She turned the Indian Ocean into a battleground

It was the fishermen community that mostly bore the brunt of Ockhi fury. While the sudden ingress of water destroyed many houses, boats and structures close to shores, the violent ocean claimed the lives of fishermen who went in search of fishes and left many stranded in the sea. The combined operation of Coastal Guard, Navy and Airforce with 16 ships, five aircrafts and four choppers have rescued at least 690 stranded fishermen from the deep sea. As the rescue operations go tough during the night, the Navy used Boeing P8i aircrafts, sensors, radar, infrared cameras, magnetic detection, surveillance camera and advanced lightweight helicopters turning the Indian Ocean into nothing less than a battleground.

6. Through Lakshadweep and Mumbai, Ockhi ended her journey near Gujarat

On December 2, the cyclone went to disrupt  Lakshadweep islands with major damages. Due to the calamity, around 500 houses damaged, uprooted coconut trees and electric poles and disturbed communication lines. On December 4, Ockhi left the islands and travelled parallel to the western coast of India to cause heavy rainfall in Maharashtra and Gujarat. Though she dumped an 8000 kg waste in Mumbai coasts, the cyclone was deeply weakened and had to end her journey near the coast of Gujarat by December 6.

mainheading: Tarang 2k17 marks the 30th annual day celebrations of Crescent Public School
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
With much glamour and grandeur, Crescent Public School celebrated ‘Tarang 2K17’, its 30th annual day celebration on Friday, December 22 at the open stage inside campus featuring unique entertaining acts by students that kept the audience spellbound. Kerala High Court Judge Justice B Kemal Pasha was the chief guest and inaugurated the formal event occupied by many educationalists and experts in the state. Kinder garden students performed a mesmerizing entertainment program on ‘Save the Earth’, while the music show performed by the school band added spice to the celebratory night.

Justice B Kemal Pasha, said “The ability to communicate is one of the most important function played out by education, as the schools enable their students not only with languages but also with the wisdom and confidence to interact with the society. The true foundation of a good education must start within the family as it is in my case, which gave me the culture and habit to know our neighbours and respect other people.”

“Parents should be in a proper communication with the school and teachers to develop such skills in their children. It is not only for the grown-up, the children also have their right to freedom and expression and how many of us are willing to accept that and let them communicate. We should allow them to travel more, as they should meet new people and observe different circumstances to mould their character for good”, he said.

While delivering the keynote address: P S Abdul Nazer, Manager, Crescent Public School & Secretary, Crescent Educational Trust said “With the 30th annual day of Crescent Public School, we are also celebrating the 32nd annual day of Crescent Educational Trust, which has transformed the educational landscape of Aluva forever. The achievements awarded to the prestigious educational institution range from arts, sports, academics and science and has shown our talents even in international stages. We are blessed with a group of committed educationalists and teachers to make best out of every child admitted here.”

M M Abdul Rahiman, Chairman, Crescent Educational Trust presided over the event while Rani John, Principal, CPS, T. P. M. Ibrahim Khan, President, Kerala CBSE School Managements Association and Zakkir Hussain, President, PTC spoke in the event.

mainheading: ‘The Daybreak’ collab with ‘Mind Mojo’ to conduct Teacher's Training at Crescent Public School
subheading: Sajitha Rasheed, the founder and chief mentor of Mind Mojo is a life skill and soft skill mentor with 21 years of experience in training and service industry. She helps corporate companies and educational institutions with skill development and personal growth of their staffs and students. She makes sure that she imparts only those lessons that she has tested, tried and found successful.
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
On Saturday, 52 teachers of Crescent Public School, Aluva had a training session on how to communicate with students effectively and make positive changes in their behaviour, jointly organised by ‘The Daybreak’ and ‘Mind Mojo’. Sajitha Rasheed, founder and chief mentor of Mind Mojo took the three-hour interactive session which addressed many of the daily life challenges faced by teachers in their teaching career. 

The training included self-reflection, understanding the process of communication, improving the verbal and non-verbal mode of communication and reframing the behaviour-correction methods. Sajitha Rasheed, chief mentor, Mind Mojo, said "self-reflection allows us to understand ourselves and know why we respond to a particular situation in a certain way. This also enables us to nurture the desirable characteristics and replace the undesirable ones.”

“The effective methods of communication can only be adopted by understanding the verbal and non-verbal systems which share a 30:70 ratio in our daily engagements. While verbal communication includes volume, rate, pitch and tone, the non-verbal system takes care of posture, gesture, eye contact and facial expressions. It is also important for teachers to learn how to convey both negative and positive feedback to their students for an effective system of schooling. Our culture often includes questions in feedback which may tend to push the listener into a defensive mode. This can be effectively replaced by statements and specificness for better communication. The effectiveness of the training can only be completed in a triangular approach to counselling with students and parents along with the teachers attending the sessions separately”, she said. 

Rani John, Principal, Crescent Public School, said "Crescent Public School is very keen to improve the schooling experience and the wellbeing of our students. We want our teachers to be better trained and skilled to deal with the challenges they face in classrooms and outside. It is certainly a fact to admit that children of our times are extremely unpredictable and often leave parents and teachers in confusion to deal them."

Sanjitha Saleem, CEO, The Daybreak, said "The way we communicate and express ourselves on the life stage is largely influenced by the school and the teachers who taught us in the classrooms. They play a crucial role in the character development and behaviour moulding of the students they take care of. It is important not only for teachers but also for students and parents to attend such sessions to influence the life positively". 

The training session also took specific questions and feedbacks regarding teaching methods and correction techniques from teachers and addressed them accordingly.

mainheading: Dr E Sreedharan wants reforms in the state’s engineering education: Governor
imgtext: Governor P Sathasivam addressing the audience at CUSAT
subheading: While speaking at a function to present Chancellor’s Award at CUSAT, recently, the Kerala Governor Justice P Sadasivam recalled his meeting with Dr E Sreedharan at Raj Bhavan last week during which the latter stressed the need for necessary reforms in the state’s engineering education.
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
India’s ‘Metro Man’ Dr E. Sreedharan has called for necessary reforms in Kerala’s engineering education on account of its poor quality. This was disclosed by none other than the Kerala Governor Justice P. Sadasivam while speaking at a function organised to present Chancellor’s Award at the Cochin University of Science and Technology (CUSAT) recently.

Dr Sreedharan had met him at Raj Bhavan and handed over a representation highlighting the poor quality of technical education in Kerala, the Governor said adding “he had listed three reasons for this kind of performance our engineering colleges had, which includes dilution in the standards of entrance exams, dilution in the grading system and the liberal examination conducted by universities. I have already forwarded a copy of the same to the chief minister's office and believe that engineering education in the state will improve in future".

“Every University operates in a geographical context and society expects a University's intervention in times of crisis or need. The recent Cyclone Ockhi was a case in point when people had questioned the efficiency of our facilities for weather prediction. I understand that the Cochin University of Science and Technology also has a powerful radar facility, but very little powers to intervene in the process of prediction.  I think institutions must take up such issues with the appropriate authority so as to enable themselves to carry out more meaningful extension activities that would connect them to people", the Governor further said.

The Governor along with Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan presented the 3rd Chancellor's Award for the best university in Kerala to Cochin University of Science and Technology (CUSAT) and the first award for best Emerging Young University to Kerala Veterinary and Animal Sciences University (KVASU) at CUSAT campus. The Chancellor's Award of Rs five crore to the best university in Kerala was established in 2015 to nurture a spirit of healthy competition among the universities for improving the quality of Higher Education, while it was in 2017, a separate award of Rs one crore for the best Emerging Young University in Kerala to create competition among newly established universities was instituted.

Speaking after presenting the awards, the Governor said he is happy that the institution of these two awards has brought in some positive changes, which will continue to enrich the state’s higher education sector in the years to come. "This year, the selection committee had prepared the application for the Chancellor’s Award with 47 components having a critical role in the quality of higher education such as academics, teaching and pedagogy methods, students profile and achievements, academic governance and other achievements from 12 universities across the state. The total score was fixed as 750. It was decided that the same yardstick of evaluation shall be followed for Emerging Young Universities also" he said.

Speaking on the occasion, the Chief Minister said that Universities must make sure that exams, evaluations and result announcements are conducted within the prescribed time limit. “Falling short in the time-bound completion of academic activities may affect the efforts of students to go for higher education and destroy the reputation of the whole state and its education sector. And this criterion should be considered while determining the merits and excellences of universities for such awards. Activities and excellence of CUSAT cannot be confined to the boundaries of the state, as it should be working towards becoming an institution listed among the best in the world” he said.

Dr J. Letha, Vice-Chancellor, CUSAT received the cash award along with the trophy and citation, while Anil Xavier IAS, Vice-Chancellor-in-charge accepted the award for KVASU. Local MLA V.K. Ebrahim Kunju, Dr Davendra Kumar Dhodawat IAS, Secretary to the Governor and Dr J. Letha, Vice-Chancellor, CUSAT also spoke.

mainheading: Ranjini who saved the dying man in Kochi honoured by Greets Public School
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
Rajini Ramachandran, the Kochi based lawyer rose to fame when she helped an accident victim to reach hospital after lying on a busy road in Kochi for more than fifteen minutes. On Saturday, Ranjini was honoured by Greets Public School during the annual day celebrations of this institution in its campus. The event had triggered an uproar in the society against people who chose not to help the dying man, while the Chief Minister and State Assembly along with many celebrities came to appreciate Ranjini.

Rajini Ramachandran said that it is important to have a mindset to help people. “Life is the most beautiful gift we all have and we all have the responsibility to save and nurture it. The beauty of this gift has to be preserved and enhanced by each individual. The act of enhancement comes out of the realisation that all living creatures are equally important, precious and priceless. It is our moral responsibility and duty to act and enhance the beauty of the life of our fellow beings”, she said.

C N Mohanan, chairman, Greater Cochin Development Authority, who had been the chief guest for this event said that the presence of Ranjini on this stage is giving a message to our students to be more courageous and compassionate towards the living beings around. “The moral reason behind the glory of this institution along with its inception of Greets Acadamy and its development as the Greets Public School is none other than Ms Edith Virginia Greet. The life of geet aunty, the social worker who came to Kochi and lived her entire life here in Kochi, is the biggest message that the institution gives to the society.”

The formal function which saw people from various sectors speaking, charity donations, awards and felicitations were continued by entertainment programs by students of Greets Public School.

mainheading: Kakkanad Bhavan’s Adarsha Vidyalaya Celebrated Annual Day
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
On Thursday, Bhavan’s Adarsha Vidyalaya, Kakkanad celebrated its 29th annual day at school premises with a formal function and variety of entertainments followed. Dr C N Ravishankar, Director, ICAR, CIFT, Kochi has been the chief guest and addressed the gathering about the importance of education and striving towards success. 

Kochi Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan Director E Ramankutty and Thrikkakara Municipal Councillor K P Sivan spoke in the event and felicitated the educational institutions, while Principal K Suresh read the school report and PTA President P V Sajeev explained the current functioning and the coming functions of parents get together, sports activities and games organised for vacation.

Dr C N Ravishankar, ICAR, CIFT, Kochi appreciated the efforts of Bhavan’s to transform the society through education and cherished in his association with the educational institution. He said “Students must know that they are in one of the most beautiful stages of life and are blessed with the service and staff members of this esteemed institution. Success not the mere result of luck but it cause years of hard work and commitment. It is very crucial to enjoy the studies and at the same time have a focus on the future. We have ample amount of opportunities in front of us and it is not just engineering and medical. We must explore such fields to ignite our true passions.”

E Ramankutty, Director, Kochi Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan, said “Education must result in the sense of oneness among the students in spite of all differences to facilitate the meaningful growth of our nation and a secular society. Education must also ignite the sense of cleanliness both inside and outside our homes with a due respect to the parents and teachers help them.” 

The event also felicitated the senior teachers of the school and distributed awards to students who had won in various activities.

mainheading: Don’t humiliate, students must be excited to reach schools: Rishi Raj Singh IPS
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
While speaking during the 14th Anniversary celebrations of St. Juliana Senior Secondary School in Perumpadappu, Excise Commissioner Rishi Raj Singh IPS envisioned his ideas on children and shared his experiences in parenting on Friday. The event presided by Fr. Antony Jelson Velassery, Priest-in-charge of Santa Maria Church also had felicitations, prize distributions and variety of entertainments.

Rishi Raj Singh IPS, Excise Commissioner, said “We must allow our children to enjoy studies and to get involved outdoor activities so that they will be enthused to reach schools. We often humiliate our children for no reason at all instead we should take time to appreciate their efforts and good intentions. All the time we are asking them to study and putting them under tremendous pressure. Which is why many of them are fleeing away or getting addicted to drugs. Students should feel comfortable in their home as well as in the schools. Encourage them to involve more in sports, extracurricular activities and to find their own passions. Parents and teachers must focus on the complete personality development of a student and not just the academics”.

Fr. Antony Jelson Velassery, Priest-in-charge of Santa Maria Church derived the meaning of a student from the word itself. He said “Self-discipline and simplicity are the two things education must aim to develop in a student. A life of devoid of luxury and strict sense of control on oneself. They also must have a thirst for wisdom which will guide them throughout their life and will give an understanding of what is good and bad. The teachers must help them to have a devotion and enthusiasm towards knowledge and to keep truthfulness in life.”

mainheading: The Wonders from the Chair- The legend bids adieu...
subheading:
"Remember to look up to the stars and not down at your feet. Try to make sense of what you see and wonder about what makes the universe exist. Be curious, And however difficult life may seem, there is always something you can do and succeed at. It matters that you don't just give up." 
-Stephen Hawkings
author: Anuja Susan Varghese
article:
One of the legendary cosmologists, scientists and physicists of our times, Prof. Stephen William Hawkings is no more. Having a lot of labels to his credit, he was truly a man who has shown the world the real meaning of the existence of life. Prof. Hawkins has always taught us to dream beyond our potential, as dreams and hopes are those guide us in our life. A great scholar who chalked out an entirely new realm for academics. His study and discovery on the theory of 'The Black Holes of the Universe' have brought him great acclaim and recognition.

His life is truly an inspirational one without any doubt. Diagnosed with ALS, a form of Motor Neurone Disease at the age of 21 and the life after that is quite a story. It has been a battle with life ever since and he was a winner always. Nothing stopped him from dreaming, he dreamt about doing wonders and strived towards it. Though he was confined to a wheelchair, his vision was far-reaching. He had made the impossible possible and has performed wonders from his wheelchair.

Prof. Hawkings has always taught the world, "The greatest enemy of knowledge is not ignorance, it is the illusion of knowledge". "I'm fairly human and normal. At least I try to be", is what his response to all those who viewed him with questioning eyes. As students, your physics syllabus will always have a space reserved for him and so will our hearts because this man is a legend who has taught the world to smile despite all odds.

mainheading: Know more about Jackfruit, just crowned as Kerala’s official fruit
subheading: Jackfruit is already revered around the world as the King of fruits and is honoured by the Bangladesh government as their National fruit due to the contributions it had to the culinary traditions of the country. In Tamil Nadu, Jackfruit is declared as the state fruit and is also one of the auspicious fruits along with Mango and Banana.
author: Db correspondent
article:
Bright days are ahead for the good old jackfruit with the Government of Kerala declaring it as the state’s official fruit recently. This decision is certain to help increase the production and open up immense opportunities for this exotic fruit. The annual production of Jackfruits in the state is valued at around Rs 60 crore. Minister for Agriculture V S Sunil Kumar, while making the announcement told the state assembly that value-added products from jackfruits can fetch an additional revenue of  Rs 30,000 crore. Let’s us have look at some of the interesting facts about this nutritious fruit variety

  • The name “Jackfruit” originated from the Malayalam language

The English word, “Jack” in jackfruit came from the Portuguese word “Jaca” which in turn was derived from the Malayalam term for the same fruit “Chakka”. Hendrick Van Rheede, the Dutch naturalist and author of ‘Hortus Malabaricus’ was the first to record this name in 1678 and then translated into different languages. The commonly used name ‘Jackfruit’ was first used by British Naturalist Garcia De Orta in 1563.

  • Jackfruit cultivation is 6000 years old

Jackfruit is native to South West India and was cultivated here even around 6000 years back, according to the archaeological evidence available. It has played a crucial role in the agricultural history of Indian Subcontinent, due to the nutritive quality of the fruit and minimal effort required to cultivate it.

  • National fruit of Bangladesh and state fruit of Tamil Nadu

Jackfruit is already revered around the world as the King of fruits and is honoured by the Bangladesh government as their National fruit due to the contributions it had to the culinary traditions of the country. In Tamil Nadu, Jackfruit is declared as the state fruit and is also one of the auspicious fruits along with Mango and Banana.

  • Jackfruit is a collection of flowers with fleshy petals

More than a fruit, Jackfruit is considered as a cluster of flowers with thick flesh which is edible. Hundreds of such bulbs are closely arranged inside the thorny skin so that to look like a fruit.

  • Indonesia have palaces built by Jackwood

The wood of Jackfruit tree is in high demand due to the termite and fungus-resistant properties. It is used in the manufacturing of furniture, musical instruments like Veena or Mrithangam and even in house construction. Bali, the Indonesian Island, has palaces made of Jackwood. It is also used to make priest’s seat in Hindu ceremonies, Buddhist statues and is even worshipped in many parts of India.

  • Jackfruit is a nutritious food with medicinal properties

While the root of a Jackfruit tree can provide medicine for treating fever, asthma and diarrhoea, it is also widely accepted as a very nutritious food and is believed to be a solution to food scarcity in many parts of the world. The unripe Jackfruit is often treated and prepared as a vegetable.

mainheading: Nick Ut, the world-renowned photographer, in town.
subheading: The famous photojournalist Nick Ut visited Kochi on March 15 and interacted with journalists and photographers
author: Db Correspondent
article:
The photograph of a wounded girl fleeing naked to escape from a Napalm bomb blast during the infamous Vietnam war of the 70s was one of the most acclaimed war photographs that shook the world consciousness.

The Vietnamese-American photojournalist Nick Ut who shot into fame with this single photograph was recently in Kerala, the land of endless charms, bringing back memories of that bygone dark era of the Vietnam War, which culminated in the unconditional withdrawal of the mighty US forces in the face of the die-hard resistance of the Viet Congs.

In 1972, Vietnam was burning under the ruthless air and land attacks. It was on June 8, 1972, photojournalist Nick Ut who was in the town of Trang Bang in South Vietnam, covering War for Associated Press (AP) captured the eye-opening visual of a local girl fleeing to escape from the fumes of a Napalm bomb blast with other children following her. This single picture portrayed the horror and ruthlessness of war in the most shocking manner than a thousand words could.

Napalm is a highly flammable sticky jelly that is used in these bombs. And the girl Kim Phuc (the nude girl in the picture) was fully covered with this substance and hence the picture got its name, the 'Napalm Girl'. People were struggling to run away from the affected areas and as Nick spotted the girl and took her to the hospital for proper treatment. With that single photograph, Nick Ut gained world recognition and he was honoured with the famous Pulitzer Prize in 1973 for this photograph. 

He was in Kerala to attend the second edition of the two-day ‘International Press Photography Festival’ jointly organised by Kerala Media Academy and the Government of Kerala in Thiruvananthapuram. He was felicitated by Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan, with the first ‘World Photographer Prize’ instituted by the Kerala Media Academy at the festival. His journey started from Thiruvananthapuram covered Kollam, Alappuzha, Kottayam and Kochi where he was welcomed by renowned poets and artists.

Actor Mammootty was among those who received him in Kochi where he visited the Archives Department and the historic township of Fort Kochi.  At Palakkad, he surprised actor Mohanlal by visiting him on the sets of his upcoming movie 'Odiyan'. Nick took leave of the state with a promise of returning with the 'Napalm Girl' next time.

mainheading: In Mattancherry, yet another green lung for Kochi
author: Db correspondent
article:
Waking up in the morning, rushing to schools or workplace and going back home dead tired! In our busy daily routine, we do require more public spaces to strengthen our social interactions and friendships. The Minister of Local Administration, K.T Jaleel inaugurated the newly renovated Karippalam Ground in Mattancherry on Saturday, highlighting the importance of this.

“Public spaces assume more importance today especially as our social interactions are now growingly getting confined to smartphones and social media” the Minister pointed out on the occasion.

Well! Social media like Facebook, Whatsapp, Twitter are those social platforms through which one expresses his/her opinions and thoughts about anything and everything under the sun. Of course, it helps our interactions, but sadly these days we are increasingly limiting ourselves to these virtual social platforms.

In Kochi, it is heartening that we still do have a few green lungs like Marine Drive, Subhash Park, Fort Kochi beach and the new Karippalam ground is a welcome addition to this list. MLAS, K. J Maxi and John Fernandez were also present on the occasion.

mainheading: Dawn  of the Digital Era at a mouse click
subheading: ‘#FUTURE’ global summit just concluded in the emerging metropolis of Kochi unfolded the prospects of an innovative digital future of great expectations
author: Anuja Susan Varghese
article:
Kochi: “We believe that knowledge is the future and that, the future is knowledge”, said the Chief Minister, Pinarayi Vijayan inaugurating ‘#Future’, the global digital summit organised by the Kerala gov﻿ernment and the industrial bodies in Kochi on March 22. More importantly, it is the first global futuristic summit organised under the auspices of the state government.

The event with the theme ‘Towards a Digital Future’ addressed six topics covering health, education, banking, retail, travel and tourism and information technology. ‘In the last 30 years much has changed and in every two years, a lot of innovations are happening in the digital world, said S. D Shibulal, Chairman, High Power IT of the state government. The social media like Facebook, Instagram, Whatsapp, Uber, Dropbox have brought technological waves all across the world.

Emerging Kerala

Kerala is fast transforming into an information technology and knowledge-based society. The importance must be given to education on both primary and secondary levels to equip them for the emerging economy. In a pioneering initiative, one thousand public hotspots with free Wi-Fi facility are being provided by the state government said the Chief Minister adding ‘Kerala is the first state to declare internet as a right of the citizens. The Chief Minister also inaugurated M Keralam app, which is meant to digitalising the online government transactions making it easier and user-friendly.

The relevance of Education

“Students are simply mugging up everything without even knowing its implications”, said Byju Raveendran, founder and CEO of BYJU’S app., an innovative learning app. He pointed out that 80% of learning takes place outside the classrooms adding: “Today most of the classes are not interactive in our schools, organic way of teaching has to be adopted to make the students fall in love with learning”.

mainheading: India’s Triumph at Commonwealth Games 2018
imgtext: The Indian saga at Gold Coast
subheading: the Indian feat at latest Commonwealth games will definitely be sung for years ahead by the sports world. Watch out for the next games in Birmingham, the venue for the 2022 edition!
author: Db Correspondent
article:
Indian teams have done pride to the nation at the just concluded Commonwealth Games in Gold Coast when the action, fun and excitement have come to an end at the grand finale of the games at Carrara Stadium. The games that take place every four years manifest the friendship between nations and share the common values for the good of humanity and peace of the world.

The triumph of Saina Nehwal marked the grand finale of India’s remarkable performance at the 2018 Commonwealth Games when she became the first Indian to win two singles Gold by defeating the celebrated Olympian P. V Sindhu. Overall, India clinched the third position by gaining 66 medals with 26 gold, 20 silver and 20 bronze. The first and the second position went to Australia (80) and England (45) respectively.

However, India’s best performance was registered way back in 2010 edition of the games in New Delhi where we bagged 101 medals comprising 38 gold, followed by 69 medals in Manchester (2002).

Stand out achievements

Amongst the medals won there were a lot of standouts including that of Manika Batra, who made history by becoming the first Indian woman to win an individual table tennis event at the Games. In the women’s table tennis event, the Indian team won its first ever Commonwealth Gold. Neeraj Chopra from Haryana became the first Indian Javelin thrower to claim a Gold medal at Games. The Gold medal won by India’s mixed badminton team is the country’s first in that category at the Games.

Altogether the Indian feat at latest Commonwealth games will definitely be sung for years ahead by the sports world. Watch out for the next games in Birmingham, the venue for the 2022 edition!

mainheading: ‘The Daybreak’, Kerala’s Pioneer Students Fortnightly Launched
author: Libin Chacko Kurian
article:
Posh Publications, Kerala has launched ‘The Daybreak’, the state’s first-ever student’s fortnightly newspaper in a well-attended function organised at the campus of Kendriya Vidayala, Port Trust, Kochi. S M Saleem, Deputy Commissioner, Kendriya Vidayala released the first copy of the fortnightly at the function in the presence of a cheerful young audience on July 04, 2018.

‘The Daybreak’ which targets the student's community aims to bridge academics with the daily life and reinstate the original vision and mission of education. The 16-page publication will have 20 issues in a year with a unique blend of news, features, columns and entertainment to help students scale new heights in academics and lead a meaningful life.

The function was followed by 'I Read', a training session on reading, led by R Narayanan, Director, Teampace Sales Academy. Dr Ajeesh Ramachandran, Consultant Psychiatrist of Government Mental Health Centre, Thrissur made a special presentation to students regarding the psychological benefits of quality reading.

Shemi Saleem, managing director, Posh Advertisers, Sanjitha Saleem, CEO and managing editor, of ‘The Daybreak’ and PM Prabhakaran, Kendriya Vidayala Port Trust, Kochi were also present on the occasion.

Reading influences character

Speaking on the occasion, S M Saleem said, "Reading helps us to travel to new places every time we read a new book and experience a culture unknown to us before. My own personal reading habit started when my father brought home the ‘Illustrated Weekly of India’ from his office. Over the years my reading got evolved from comics to mystery novels and from thrillers to serious research into biology, a subject that is close to my heart and became my career."

"Reading has a direct influence on the character and behaviour of an individual which may reflect in the societal level. A society that reads will be more peaceful in nature. I hope 'The Daybreak' can induce reading habit among school children and develop reading as a culture. I appreciate Sanjitha Saleem and her team for their efforts to reach children and influence them for good", he added.

Quality of reading matters

Dr Ajeesh Ramachandran in his address said, "reading also comes with tremendous psychological effects and on that basis, the process can be divided into content reading and pleasure reading. While content reading helps us to find information and acquire knowledge, pleasure reading is reading what you love reading. As these processes are carried out by two different sections of the brain, left and right; combining both will have a positive psychological effect on a human being. So it's great if you love what you have to read."

"We can observe the negative effects of disconnection in children with learning disabilities. And a simple change in learning methods with more engaging modes can solve the problems. It is also important to find a balance in everything we do including reading, as too much of it can cause addiction. Quality of reading is what matters and movements like 'The Daybreak' will make our children more wise and sensitive" he added.

Sanjitha Saleem in her speech said "The Daybreak is a dream venture of Posh Publications which aims to serve the next generation student population. The fortnightly is conceived as a bridge between the academics and the life outside. The whole thrust is on the real purpose of education i.e. To live well and die well."

mainheading: Safety cover for school kids with the new academic year
author: Db correspondent
article:
On the commencement of the new academic year, Kochi city police have issued a notification to the school management and parents to ensure the safety of children both inside the school and while travelling. Nodal officers are assigned to each school in the city along with two other officers, who are designated to ensure the safety of children while boarding and de-boarding the bus during the busy school hours. The police have also warned parents against sending their children in over-crowded buses to schools.

 “Police officers are assigned at all school gates to help children cross the road, board the bus safely, regulate vehicle speed at school premises and to look into misbehaving against children. People violating the order will be punished,” said MP Dinesh IPS, City Police Commissioner. School authorities have been strictly warned of running a background check of the person commuting the children to avoid misbehaviour with children and made it mandatory that each member of the bus should possess a police clearance certificate. In case of violation, parents and the students are free to lodge a complaint with the nearest police station.

 Also, a private bus running in the city should allow students to board and de-board at the specific stops designated. Timely inspection of the school buses, school-owned or private, will be conducted from day one. Those running on LPG gas are expected to meet all the necessary safety measures for transporting school students. Over-speeding vehicles and drunken drivers will face stern action from the force.

 Further, strict orders have been given to punish those found selling tobacco products within a 100-metre radius of all educational institutions. Additionally, school management has been ordered to set up a complaint box and maintain a visitor’s register. Police have also advised the authorities to install CCTV cameras in the school premises. Strict action will be taken against unauthorised parking in front of schools, while also acting against illegally installed advertisement boards. For any queries, students can directly contact the SP on 9497996979. The notification has also asked parents to advise their children, to obey the instructions of the officer stationed in front of the school.

In 2017, soon after re-opening, 92 school drivers were booked for drunk driving and the police force are expected to remain extra vigil to avoid repetition of the same.

mainheading: In Ernakulam, 313 ponds get a fresh lease of life
author: Db correspondent
article:
Under the celebrated ‘Harithakerlam’ Project, Ernakulam district sets an example in terms of protecting and preserving water sources by cleaning and renovating 313 public ponds across 46 panchayats and 3 municipalities under its jurisdiction till May 2018. Led by District Collector, Muhammed Y Safirulla, the project that enjoyed public support in huge numbers were completed in three phases since 2016. Under the banner of ‘Ente Kullam Ernakulam’ 55 public ponds in 2016,

Funds for the renovation of ponds comes from Cochin Shipyard’s public funding share and minor irrigation department’s ‘Harithakeralam’ project.

mainheading: Half marathon on July 15 to fight drug abuse
author: Db correspondent
article:
With an aim to make the public aware of the ill-effects of drug use, Kerala State Mission for Drug De-addiction, ‘Vimukthi’ has decided to organise a half marathon in Kochi on July 15, 2018, few days after the International Day Against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking falling on June 26.  P T Thomas MLA and excise commissioner Rishiraj Singh released the logo of the event on June 2, 2018, at Kakkanad.

 Starting from Maharaja’s college, the half marathon with over 1000 participants divided into different groups based on age and sex, will end at Fort Kochi. The half-marathon named “Cochin Monsoon Marathon Run Against Drugs” will flag off at 6 am on July 15th. Before the event, there will be awareness programmes at different educational institutions throughout the state where the public can also attend.

The half marathon also expects involvement of high schools, higher secondary schools, colleges, NSS, NCC, YMCA, resident associations, members of governmental, non-governmental organisations and religious organisations in the city.

mainheading: A Green Take-Off of the New Academic Year
author: Db correspondent
article: Commencement of the new academic year this in Ernakulam district was noted for its focus on green living. The Ernakulam Revenue District-level ‘Praveshanolsavam’ (School opening ceremony) was inaugurated by Anoop Jacob MLA on June 01, 2018 at Government LP School Maneed near Pirvaom. All the festive preparations organised by the general education department and the ‘Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan’ in the district were strictly adhering to the green protocol. The students of Vennala Government LP School in the district took a pledge saying ‘no’ to plastics and the organisers decorated the venue with palm leaves, paper flowers.

mainheading: NCERT for a Complete Syllabus Revamp
subheading: It’s good news that NCERT is planning to revise the existing syllabus with a view to adding more value to the content.
author: Db Correspondent
article:
The National Council of Educational Research and Training (NCERT) is on a mission to drastically update their existing syllabus for the new academic year focussing more on life skills, sports and values. According to the Union Ministry of Human Resource Development (HRD) in the first week of June, the new syllabus will have its size reduced to half. There will be more on scientific achievements of ancient India with toned down political commentaries.

Prakash Javadekar, Minister of HRD, said “Education is not just memorising and putting it down on the answer sheet. Education is comprehensive. To put to use one’s cognitive and analytical abilities—that is true education. The NCERT syllabus is so cramped. Hence we have decided to reduce the syllabus by half”.

Value Addition

The NCERT has so far made 1,334 changes, which include additions, corrections and data update, in its 182 textbooks. Of these, 573 changes have been made to Science books, followed by 316 changes in Social Science and 163 changes in Sanskrit textbooks. NCERT is also is considering a proposal named ‘Energised Textbooks’ with digital links to multimedia material where concepts will be explained through diagrams, charts and data.

The academic body had earlier dropped several “offensive” cartoons from its Political Science textbooks and has gone a step further and toned down the commentary on Indian politics and politicians in its Class 10 textbook. Looking forward to a major change, the ministry has already received 37,000 suggestions on how classes, subjects and lessons can be improved to teach students about life skills, value education, and physical education.

NCERT will also be adding contents on the glorious ancient past of India ranging from Yoga and Upanishads to scientific achievements and topics like Ayurveda.

mainheading: Chennai Developer Bags the Apple Design Award
author: Db correspondent
article:
Little did Raja Vijayaram from Chennai know while packing his bag to attend the Apple Worldwide Developers Conference (WWDC) that he would be awarded the prestigious Apple awards for his elegantly designed calculator app, Calzy 3. Raja was flown to San Jose, USA to receive the Apple Design Award, on June 04, 2018, the first day of the Developer’s Annual Conference of Apple.Inc without being told he was the winner!

The Calzy 3 app is as simple as a calculator can be. You can view each and every step you are following to get the answer. There is a scientific calculator too hidden inside which can be pulled up with a 3D touch. The interesting part of Raja’s Calzy is that there is a bookmark option for any earlier calculations. The app is completely customisable and you can protect all your tax amounts away with a password.

Calzy 3 was first launched by the one army man in 2014. The latest one is the revamped version of the earlier. The app is only available for iOS priced at Rs. 159. Being a mechanical engineer from Theni, Raja moved into VFX some years ago and worked for a few movies in Chennai. He bought his first iPhone to use and learn about the apps, later he began coding the apps. Though flooded with requests for more features, Raja wants to keep his calculations with Calzy as simple as possible. 

Apple Design Awards, also known as the ADA is a special event hosted by Apple Inc. at its annual Worldwide Developers Conference to recognize the best and most innovative Macintosh and iOS software and hardware produced by independent developers. This year 10 apps were awarded the Apple Design Award. 

They are the Finnish Bandimal from Yatatoy, a composing app for children which is sensational, Agenda, the note-taking app for Mac and iOS that focuses on dates, iTranslate Converse, a speedy and efficient translator designed for conversations, Alto’s Odyssey, an app teaching gamers how to play, Calzy 3, Frost, puzzle game, Triton Sponge, an app used in medical operating rooms to measure blood loss collected by surgical sponges and suction canisters, Oddmar, another game.

mainheading: BIKOS: A Project to Ensure Cyber Safety in Campus
author: Megha Thomas
article:
In a commendable initiative aimed at providing a safe cyber world for the students in the campus, several CBSE schools in Ernakulam district have joined to adopt 'Better Internet for Kids Online Security' (Bikos), a project launched by Cochin Refinery School.

Bikos is a project focusing on training and sensitizing school children, with the ultimate objective of creating a safe cyber policy. CBSE has mandated a cyber policy in every school to ensure safe browsing world for the children.

“The project works under various phases. In the first phase, there will be a brainstorming session with the principals where the problems of cybersecurity at schools are discussed. The second phase involves handing over the output of the brainstorming session to school councillors, where solutions are found to the problems. In the next phase, we get experts from Kerala Police and cyber lawyers to help us out,” Premalatha Shaji, coordinator of BIKOS project told The Daybreak.

Bikos was initially launched last year, organising training sessions and awareness campaigns for both students and parents. This year, the Kerala Police, cyber experts and lawyers are being involved in these programmes. The training programmes are conducted in association with Amrita Institute of Medical Sciences.

As part of the project, the schools have approached Kerala High Court lawyer, Prem Kamath to formulate a campus-specific cyber policy that would go hand in hand with the internet laws of the country.

Talking to ‘The Daybreak’, Kamath said, “The policy will be formulated based on the guidelines given by CBSE which requires that schools affiliated to them need to have mandatory cyber policies for themselves to protect children in the online environment and also to look into the usage of electronic gadgets at school.”

With 30 CBSE schools working under the project, Bikos also organises courses to students as well as awareness programmes and projects for teachers

mainheading: Kerala Kalolsavam sans pomp to be held in Alappuzha
subheading: undefined
author: Db correspondent
article:
Despite the woes of Kerala in the backdrop of the recent natural calamity, the government has decided to conduct the annual school youth festival without any fanfare or frills in December at Alappuzha.

The decision taken at the special initiative of Chief Minister, Pinarayi Vijayan is to see that the students do not miss grace marks that could be earned on account of their performance at Kalolsavam.

It may be noted that the government had cancelled most of the regular festivities this year including the youth festival and International Film Festival in view of the widespread damage caused by the recent floods that devastated entire Kerala. The government has also decided to donate all the funds allotted for these festivals to be transferred to the Chief Minister’s relief fund and imposed a year-long ban on any state-sponsored programmes or celebrations.

Meanwhile, the sports fest will be held in Thiruvananthapuram in October while the science fair will be held in Kannur in December. The special school festival will be held in October at Kollam.

article:
Despite the woes of Kerala in the backdrop of the recent natural calamity, the government has decided to conduct the annual school youth festival without any fanfare or frills in December at Alappuzha. The decision taken at the special initiative of Chief Minister, Pinarayi Vijayan is to see that the students do not miss grace marks that could be earned on account of their performance at Kalolsavam.
